content.question: In a modern aircraft with 3 AC generators (two turbine engines and an APU), the generators all fail, and only battery power remains. How would the essential AC bus be powered?

options.A: It would not be powered as there are no AC sources remaining.
options.B: It contains its own battery which directly provides AC power in case of an outage.
options.C: It is powered by the main battery via an inverter, to keep essential AC consumers running in the event of a total generation failure.
options.D: It is directly connected to the main battery to power essential aircraft controls and components.

key_points: Almost all aircraft require AC (alternating current) and DC (direct current) power for various consumers
All modern large jet aircraft generate power as AC, and any consumers that require DC are fed by a separate circuit of DC power
AC must be "rectified" into DC, and aircraft use transformer rectifier units (TRUs) to do this, as well as reducing the voltage to the correct level (usually 115 V AC to 28 V DC)
learning.explanation: Almost all aircraft require AC (alternating current) and DC (direct current) power for various consumers. All modern large jet aircraft generate power as AC, and any consumers that require DC are fed by a separate circuit of DC power. AC must be "rectified" into DC, and aircraft use transformer rectifier units (TRUs) to do this, as well as reducing the voltage to the correct level (usually 115 V AC to 28 V DC). This DC circuit is also what charges the batteries, as batteries can only use DC. This question asks about the other direction though, from DC to AC, assuming all the AC generators have failed and the aircraft batteries have a limited supply of DC power available. To power the AC components with DC, it must be "inverted", to turn the flat voltage of DC into a sine wave voltage of AC. A static inverter does this, so AC equipment can run off the DC battery in the event of an AC generation failure.

content.question:
Which of the following formulas describes how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current and the resulting RPM.
T = Torque, U = Voltage, H = RPM, I = Current.

options.A: T = U × H × I
options.B: T = (U × I) / H

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.01: Describe how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current, and the resulting magnetic fields within the motor. The derivation for this formula can be taken from Power = Torque x RPM That is an easy to remember formula which works for engines and motors, and can be reasoned that the power output is just the individual turning force (torque) multiplied by how many times we can apply it over a certain time (RPM). When rearranged, it becomes Torque = Power / RPM As the power of an electrical circuit can be measured using Power = Voltage x Current this means that Torque = (Voltage x Current) / RPM When you substitute this question's nomenclature into that formula, it becomes T = (U × I) / H

options.B: directly connected to the battery.
options.C: kept in operating conditions by an electrical resistance in the case of energy failure.
options.D: automatically connected to the battery if generators have failed.

key_points: A Hot Bus or Direct Bus is directly connected to the battery, also known as a “battery bus bar”
The vital consumers are connected to this Bus so they’re always provided with electrical power
« A means of providing an alternative current » - INCORRECT, as batteries only supply DC current
learning.explanation: A Hot Bus or Direct Bus is directly connected to the battery, also known as a “battery bus bar”. The vital consumers are connected to this Bus so they’re always provided with electrical power. « A means of providing an alternative current » - INCORRECT, as batteries only supply DC current. « Kept in operating conditions by an electrical resistance in the case of energy failure » - INCORRECT, this is a nonsense answer option as resistance is not something that will is able to run an electrical circuit and keep a hot bus operating. « Automatically connected to the battery if generators have failed » - INCORRECT, because the batteries are always connected to the DC BAT bus.

content.question: An advantage of nickel-cadmium compared with lead-acid batteries is that they…

options.A: maintain a constant output voltage during discharge.
options.B: are less prone to thermal runaway.
options.C: have a higher internal resistance which produces more power.
options.D: do not require venting as the cells are sealed during manufacture.

key_points: Lead Acid Batteries Anode made of lead peroxide, Cathode made of spongy lead
Both plates suspended in a electrolyte solution of water and sulphuric acid
Good energy storage They are heavy Low energy density If overcharged, the water/sulphuric acid can boil and cause evaporation and damage the plates
learning.explanation: Lead Acid Batteries Anode made of lead peroxide, Cathode made of spongy lead. Both plates suspended in a electrolyte solution of water and sulphuric acid. Good energy storage They are heavy Low energy density If overcharged, the water/sulphuric acid can boil and cause evaporation and damage the plates. Temperature affected: the discharge rate of a lead acid battery decreases with a decrease in temperature and vice versa. This is because the internal resistance increases at lower temperatures. Voltages: On lad: 2 volts Off lad 2.2 volts Replacement: belw 1.8 volts, and below 1.17 Specific gravity Nickel Cadmium Batteries (NiCad or NiCd) The plates are made of Nickel Oxide and Cadmium which are both suspended in a electrolyte solution of potassium hydroxide. Very low change in voltage during discharge, remains relatively the same around 1.2 volts. Low internal resistance Low maintenance Reliable Wide operating temperatures Thermal runaway: the heat generated in certain is more than what the batterie can dissipate, leading to a rapid increase in temperature. This higher temperature leads to a lower internal resistance causing an increase in charging current, therefore multiplying the effect even more. If not monitored, the battery may be completely destroyed during charging. Voltages: On lad: 1.2 volts To answer the question, nickel-cadmium batteries: Maintain a more constant voltage during discharge (Correct!) Are more prone to thermal runaway Have a lower internal resistance NiCad batteries do require venting

content.question:
On a modern transport aircraft, an engine driven generator supplying one of the main AC busbars develops a fault and is switched off by the flight crew.
Choose the incorrect statement.

options.A: The FCOM and/or aircraft status page should be consulted by the flight crew to determine the aircraft’s landing capability.
options.B: As a result, the affected AC busbar will be without power until the flight crew selects the AC alternate feed switch.
options.C: The opposite engine driven generator will take-over and provide power to both main AC busbars.
options.D: The flight crew should start the APU as an alternate means of AC power.

key_points: This question asks for the incorrect statement
“The flight crew should start the APU as an alternate means of AC power
” Correct
learning.explanation: This question asks for the incorrect statement. “The flight crew should start the APU as an alternate means of AC power.” Correct. Since the aircraft is down to a single source of AC power, the flight crew is advised to start the APU to re-established two sources of AC power and reduced the load on the single engine driven generator. “The FCOM and/or aircraft status page should be consulted by the flight crew to determine the aircraft’s landing capability.” Correct. An engine driven generator failure will downgrade the aircraft’s landing capability. This can be checked by the flight crew in the FCOM and aircraft status page. “The opposite engine driven generator will take-over and provide power to both main AC busbars.” Correct. Modern complex aircrafts are generally equipped with two AC engine driven generators. Should one of them develop a fault, the remaining engine driven generator will take-over.

content.question: When using a fuse with a higher rating than prescribed…

options.A: Overcurrent might go undetected and cause a fire.
options.B: The current in the circuit will be too high, resulting in a blown fuse.
options.C: The whole circuit will overheat, which is a potential fire hazard.
options.D: It will take too much time to detect an open circuit.

key_points: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur

Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects
If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit
learning.explanation: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur. Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects. If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit. It could cause a failure of the device burn it up, start a fire. The fuse is designed as a safety device. It should not only be the correct amperage but also the correct voltage and fast or slow blow. In other words, if an over-current is allowed - by fitting an incorrect fuse rating, for example - there is a severe risk of an electrical fire. However, it is important to note that, in a healthy circuit, nothing will happen as long as the circuit does not encounter an overload condition. If the circuit does encounter an overload condition then that part of the circuit that the fuse protects may become a fire hazard. Note: Some students have confirmed that the option "Overcurrent might go undetected and cause a fire." was correct in their exams and confirmed that the option "In a healthy system nothing problematic will happen." was not within the available answers. However, we have also received a couple of feedback confirming the correct option to be "In a healthy system nothing problematic will happen." which makes us believe that there are at least two similar question.

content.question: A Constant Speed Drive (CSD) of an AC generator may be disconnected in flight. What is/are the typical primary reason for disconnection?

options.A: An excessive variation of voltage and kVAR.
options.B: Illumination of the CSD disconnect warning light.
options.C: A slight variation about the normal operating frequency.
options.D: Low oil pressure and/or high oil temperature of the generator drive.

key_points: Constant Speed Drive (CSD) The Constant Speed Drive (CSD) is a mainly mechanical device, which is positioned between the aeroplane engine and the brushless AC generator
The CSD is designed to keep the generator running at a constant speed
Excessive Constant Speed Drive (CSD) oil temperature, low pressures and low oil levels indicate an impending failure of the CSD
learning.explanation: Constant Speed Drive (CSD) The Constant Speed Drive (CSD) is a mainly mechanical device, which is positioned between the aeroplane engine and the brushless AC generator. The CSD is designed to keep the generator running at a constant speed. Excessive Constant Speed Drive (CSD) oil temperature, low pressures and low oil levels indicate an impending failure of the CSD. If any of these occur, there will be an indication on the flight deck to alert the flight crew. To prevent damage to the accessory gearbox and engine, the pilot is required to disconnect the CSD in flight through a "dog clutch" remotely operated from the flight deck. It can be reconnected on the ground.

The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply

learning.explanation: Batteries convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a transfer of electrons from one material to another using the potential difference between the materials. The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply. For example, a 5 Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2.5 Amperes in 2 hours, or even 10 amperes in 30 minutes. If two identical batteries are connected in parallel the output voltage will remain the same and the capacity expressed in ampere-hours will double. On the other hand, if the batteries are connected in series, the capacity will remain the same, but the output voltage will double.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding DC electric motors?
1. If a motor seizes, then the the applied EMF is equal to the back EMF
2. If a motor seizes, then the applied EMF is equal to the net EMF
3. If there is a motor runaway, the applied EMF is equal to the back EMF
4. If there is a motor runaway, the back EMF is equal to the net EMF

options.A: 1 and 3.
options.B: 1 and 4.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.03: Explain the consequences of the following: rotor seizure; rotor runaway. Back EMF is a backwards voltage that runs through a DC motor armature circuit, and increases with the speed of the motor. It acts like a motor speed regulator. EMF stands for electromotive force, and remember that EMF = voltage. Applied EMF - back EMF = net EMF Input voltage - back EMF = useful voltage Given that EMF increases with rotor speed, when the rotor speed is zero (the motor has yet to spin or has seized), there is no back EMF. Therefore, If a motor seizes, all the applied EMF is able to become net EMF, so applied EMF = net EMF. The opposite occurs if a motor suffers a runaway, where there is no load (therefore no net EMF) applied to slow the motor down. In this case, the high speed of the motor causes an increase in the back EMF, until the back EMF equals the applied EMF. This means the motor has a maximum speed that it can possible turn at, when the back EMF equals the voltage of the circuit.

content.question: One of the purposes of the starter-generator is to…

options.A: start the core engine until reaching self-sustaining speed.
options.B: drive the generator until the engine takes over.
options.C: excite the magnetic field when the generator is still.
options.D: generate electrical power until reaching self-sustaining speed.

key_points: A starter-generator combines, as it names suggests, the functions of both the starter and the generator

In fact, it is a unit that besides functioning as an air starter to spool up the engine, it also has a second series of windings that will allow it to switch to a generator after the engine core has reached a self-sustaining speed
When speaking about the engine core, it is referred to the HP compressor since the starter generator is permanently engaged to the shaft through a set of drive gears at the HP compressor stage
learning.explanation: A starter-generator combines, as it names suggests, the functions of both the starter and the generator. In fact, it is a unit that besides functioning as an air starter to spool up the engine, it also has a second series of windings that will allow it to switch to a generator after the engine core has reached a self-sustaining speed. When speaking about the engine core, it is referred to the HP compressor since the starter generator is permanently engaged to the shaft through a set of drive gears at the HP compressor stage. This type of generator is a simple shunt wind generator but with more winding as it is needed to produce a strong field and provide a high torque for starting. The main reason for using a starter generator is to reduce weight and therefore money on fuel burn and maintenance.

content.question: The function of a NOT logic gate within a circuit is to…

options.A: process only high voltage input signals.
options.B: invert the input signal such that the output is always of the opposite state.
options.C: accept the input signal only if it is AC.
options.D: ensure the output signal is of the same state as the input signal.

key_points: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices
An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result
The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate
learning.explanation: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices. An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result. The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted AND output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted OR output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question:
Regarding the capacity of a battery and its measurement, which statement(s) is/are correct/incorrect?
1. The battery capacity is determined by multiplying a current flow in Amperes by the time in hours that the battery is being discharged
2. The total battery capacity is dependent on the voltage rating of its battery cells

options.A: 1. incorrect; 2. incorrect.
options.B: 1. correct; 2. incorrect.

key_points: Batteries are rated according to the number of volts and number of ampere hours
The latter rating specifies how many amperes can be discharged by a fully charged battery over a given period of time before the battery is drained
In simple words, it is determined by how many amperes it can supply over a given period of time
learning.explanation: Batteries are rated according to the number of volts and number of ampere hours. The latter rating specifies how many amperes can be discharged by a fully charged battery over a given period of time before the battery is drained. In simple words, it is determined by how many amperes it can supply over a given period of time. The battery capacity depends on the physical size of the battery plates, and not on the voltage rating.

content.question: What should a flight crew do following the loss of all fuel indications?

options.A: Recycle the circuit breaker, if it's part of a procedure, and check if the system restarts.
options.B: Land as soon as possible and prepare for power off landing.
options.C: Turn off fuel pumps for 10 min and then turn them back on.
options.D: Open the cross-feed valve to make sure the aeroplane stays in balance.

key_points: LO 021
learning.explanation: LO 021.09.01.07.04 : Describe how circuit breakers may be used to reset aircraft systems/computers in the event of system failure (when part of a described procedure). Pulling and resetting the circuit breakers are usually the first items on the checklist on such an occasion. Unless otherwise advised, it should be the first thing to do. This avoids a potentially costly diversion for the case of a simple electronic fault. Of course, it is important to continually monitor the fuel level and corresponding indications. If this was a fuel leak (which is the worst case scenario), it would be important to fly to the nearest suitable airport and land immediately, however, this will probably be an early part of the checklist if a fuel leak/fault is diagnosed/expected. content.question: What is a Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) used for?

options.B: To convert from AC to DC, usually to a higher voltage.
options.C: To convert from AC to DC, usually to a lower voltage.
options.D: To convert from DC to AC, usually to a lower voltage.

key_points: A Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) is a transformer and rectifier in the same unit
It is used in an AC system to power the DC busbar and charge the batteries
Therefore, it converts AC to DC (it "rectifies" the current)
learning.explanation: A Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) is a transformer and rectifier in the same unit. It is used in an AC system to power the DC busbar and charge the batteries. Therefore, it converts AC to DC (it "rectifies" the current). Most large aircraft use 115/200 V AC generators to supply the electrical needs of the aircraft. The DC busbars are supplied by Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU). The transformer changes the voltage from 115 V to 28 V, the rectifier converts the 28 V AC to 28 V DC. Therefore, it usually lowers the voltage.

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

1. By increasing the load on an electric motor (i.e. increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow
2. The torque of an electrical motor can be calculated by dividing the power by the motor RPM

options.A: 1 and 2 are both correct.
options.B: 1 and 2 are both incorrect.

key_points: “1) By increasing the load on an electric motor (i
e
increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow
learning.explanation: “1) By increasing the load on an electric motor (i.e. increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow.” Correct. An increased resistance against rotation will result in a slower motor RPM. Consequently, back emf reduces. Such reduction will cause the current to increase. Power output = voltage x current Voltage remains constant, whilst current increases => therefore power will also increase. “2) The torque of an electrical motor can be calculated by dividing the power by the motor RPM.” Correct. In simple words, torque is the twisting force which makes a motor turn. An electrical motor’s torque can be calculated by dividing the power (voltage x current) by the motor RPM: Torque = (Voltage x Current) / RPM

options.A: By the transformer rectifier unit (TRU).
options.B: By the static inverter.

key_points: In an aircraft without a dedicated battery charging system, the batteries are typically charged by a transformer rectifier unit (TRU)
A TRU is an electrical device that converts the alternating current (AC) from the aircraft's main electrical power source into direct current (DC) to charge the batteries
The TRU is connected to the aircraft's main power bus and regulates the voltage and current to ensure that the batteries are charged safely and efficiently
learning.explanation: In an aircraft without a dedicated battery charging system, the batteries are typically charged by a transformer rectifier unit (TRU). A TRU is an electrical device that converts the alternating current (AC) from the aircraft's main electrical power source into direct current (DC) to charge the batteries. The TRU is connected to the aircraft's main power bus and regulates the voltage and current to ensure that the batteries are charged safely and efficiently. The TRU also provides power to other DC electrical systems on the aircraft, such as the lighting and avionics systems.

content.question: The metal box around a lithium battery is designed to contain.

options.A: Thermal runaway.
options.B: Electrolyte for the cells.

key_points: Internal short circuits may occur in a lithium-ion battery due to, for instance, lithium dendrite formation or a compressive shock
A prolonged internal short circuit results in self discharge in combination with a local temperature increase

The latter effect is important because the electrolyte may start to decompose by exothermic reactions if the temperature reaches a certain threshold, causing thermal runaway with potential health and safety hazards
learning.explanation: Internal short circuits may occur in a lithium-ion battery due to, for instance, lithium dendrite formation or a compressive shock. A prolonged internal short circuit results in self discharge in combination with a local temperature increase. The latter effect is important because the electrolyte may start to decompose by exothermic reactions if the temperature reaches a certain threshold, causing thermal runaway with potential health and safety hazards. Lithium battery storage boxes are used as thermal runaway protection. These are made from galvanised or stainless steel, and incorporate fire insulation materials.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to resetting a tripped circuit breaker in flight?

options.A: An immediate reset is the first action that should be tried to quickly achieve system functionality again.
options.B: In-flight resets can be done safely at least 3 times, thereafter, proceed according to the relevant checklist.
options.C: Reset of circuit brakes during flight is impossible; it can only be done when on ground.
options.D: An immediate reset should NOT be attempted unless the source of the overcurrent has been safely removed.

key_points: A circuit breaker is a thermally or magnetically operated mechanical device that replaces the functions of a fuse and is today the most commonly used overload protection device
Once operated because of excess current, the device can be reset only once

If a circuit breaker trips while you’re flying, it’s okay to reset it ONCE after allowing a minute or two for it to cool, even if you have no idea what caused it to trip and cut off electrical power to a particular circuit
learning.explanation: A circuit breaker is a thermally or magnetically operated mechanical device that replaces the functions of a fuse and is today the most commonly used overload protection device. Once operated because of excess current, the device can be reset only once. If a circuit breaker trips while you’re flying, it’s okay to reset it ONCE after allowing a minute or two for it to cool, even if you have no idea what caused it to trip and cut off electrical power to a particular circuit. Only if the breaker trips a second time should you not try to restore power by resetting it. Excessive resetting of the circuit and therefore allowing the potentially overcurrent to flow could damage systems and electrical damage could potentially become worse

Refer to figure.
There is a generator control switch on the flight deck. Using the annex above, which generator does this switch directly control?

options.A: The main generator.
options.B: The tacho generator.

key_points: The diagram shows the "Gen control switch" as highlighted in the annex above
when the generator is switched off, the switch to the left is opened, and activates the solenoid just above, opening the switch above on the voltage control line
This line feeds the exciter generator field coil from the voltage regulator
learning.explanation: The diagram shows the "Gen control switch" as highlighted in the annex above. when the generator is switched off, the switch to the left is opened, and activates the solenoid just above, opening the switch above on the voltage control line. This line feeds the exciter generator field coil from the voltage regulator. When the switch is pushed (off), the exciter generator will no longer produce any current, hence the exciter generator is directly controlled by the switch. The diagram is pretty complex, and does not include absolutely everything about a permanent magnet generator AC alternator, but if you wish to know how it works, the explanation below may help. Brushless AC Alternators (PMG Type) Modern aircraft AC generators are predominantly self-exciting brushless alternators, and often incorporate a permanent magnet generator. To explain this, we are going to work backwards, from what we want our final output to be, to how we get every component of that to work. A generator is made up of a magnetic field (either produced by permanent magnets or by an electric "field" coil which acts like a magnet) and an armature coil. One of those is spinning (rotor) and the other is stationary (stator), and which is which is decided by the input and outputs required. The armature is where AC power is generated, from the rotational energy inputted by the spinning shaft (often from an engine via constant speed drive). The basis of an AC alternator/generator (for AC output they mean the same thing) is that we wish to have the output armature windings on the stator of the main generator, so we can send the AC power straight to the bus bars. This means that the field windings on the main generator must be mounter to the rotor. This main generator is where we make the power to output to the aircraft distribution system. The voltage of the main generator is regulated by changing the strength of the magnetic field, which just means changing the voltage through the field coil. So we somehow need a way to feed voltage-regulated DC power to a spinning coil rotating at 400 Hz. We do this by having a second generator, the exciter generator, mounted on the same shaft, with the rotor this time being the armature coils (and the stator is therefore the magnetic field producer). The spinning armatures generate 3 phase AC current which is sent through a spinning rectifier to produce the field coil for the main generator. The magnetic field for the exciter generator is provided by a DC supply from the voltage regulator. If the voltage output of the main generator drops, the voltage regulator increases the voltage to the exciter field coil, and the voltage of the main generator field will increase, increasing the final output voltage. Initial excitement can be provided by a permanent magnet generator, a third generator on the same shaft, this time with a permanent magnet (field) mounter on the rotor, and the armature (stator) picking up an AC supply, then rectifying it and using it to power the exciter field or the voltage regulator, etc. When the shaft begins spinning, this will be the first thing to produce any current.

key_points: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices
An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result

learning.explanation: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices. An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result. The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted AND output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted OR output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question: Circuit breakers are used to protect…

options.A: only DC circuits.
options.B: AC and DC circuits.

key_points: Circuit breakers (CBs) combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit
They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch
Therefore, besides providing protection to an AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances
learning.explanation: Circuit breakers (CBs) combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit. They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch. Therefore, besides providing protection to an AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances. Circuit breakers are special because even after the circuit breaker has tripped, the circuit can be closed again, thus allowing to restore the circuit and potentially power important systems. We say that the circuit breaker is resettable (which a fuse is not). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the bimetallic and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, good for some systems but not for others. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch to trip the breaker immediately.

content.question: Which circuit breaker is used with a bimetallic strip that typically causes a delayed trip, depending on the severity of the overcurrent?

options.A: thermal circuit breaker
options.B: magnetic circuit breaker

key_points: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts)
The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs
The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together
learning.explanation: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high for too long, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, which is good for some systems but not for others. The higher the overcurrent, the faster the thermal CB will trip. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch (solenoid) to trip the breaker almost instantly. Obviously, it cannot be absolutely instant, as things take time to move and therefore a very short overcurrent will still be experienced by the circuit.

content.question: What will happen if a bus bar has a short circuit? The affected bus...

options.A: is isolated and consumers fed by another generator.
options.B: consumers are no longer fed.

key_points: Bus bars are a way of simplifying the distribution of electrical power through a network
They are thick copper bars with holes drilled in, where wiring can be attached to be split to go to other locations/consumers within a network
They can run off one or multiple sources of power, and are much simpler and lighter than individual wiring to every generator/consumer
learning.explanation: Bus bars are a way of simplifying the distribution of electrical power through a network. They are thick copper bars with holes drilled in, where wiring can be attached to be split to go to other locations/consumers within a network. They can run off one or multiple sources of power, and are much simpler and lighter than individual wiring to every generator/consumer. A short circuit is where electricity finds an easier way to flow from high voltage to low voltage. Usually, we want that electricity to flow through our consumer, which has some resistance, but if a significantly easier route exists, the amount of current running through a consumer will decrease, as an easier path exists for the electricity. If, for instance, a loose, uninsulated wire going straight to "ground" touched a bus bar, then all the electricity available to the bus bar would begin to flow through this wire, as it is the easiest path to go from high voltage to low voltage, completing the circuit. This would not only be a fire hazard, as the high current would heat all components up far too much, but would also mean that all connected consumers would not receive any electrical current, and would stop working. Think of it like a "black hole" for electricity, all the current will be sucked down the short circuit and will not feed other consumers. To avoid this eventuality, bus bars have circuit breakers that will disconnect above a certain current. This meant that the bus bar will become isolated from the other circuits in the aircraft, and no more electricity will be lost due to this short circuit. It does, however, mean that the consumers that only take power from that bus bar will be unable to receive power for the rest of the flight.

options.C: if the terminals are short-circuited, causing rapid and high current flow, heat and risk of explosion.

key_points: The biggest threat to Lithium-ion batteries is thermal runaway
Thermal runaway of the lithium-ion battery initiates an unstoppable chain reaction

learning.explanation: The biggest threat to Lithium-ion batteries is thermal runaway. Thermal runaway of the lithium-ion battery initiates an unstoppable chain reaction. The temperature rises rapidly within milliseconds and the energy stored in the battery is suddenly released. Several factors can lead to thermal runaway of a lithium-ion battery: Internal short circuit: Due to an accident or similar mechanical impact, e.g. if a tool falls down from a great height, the battery is deformed, material penetrates the battery cell and triggers an internal short circuit. External short circuit: Deformation of the battery cell causes an external short circuit. Overcharging the battery beyond the maximum voltage specified in the data sheet. Depending on the degree of overcharging, the battery may be damaged permanently and the service life of the battery decreases. Overheating/Excessive currents when charging. Recharging a Li-ion battery will cause the temperature of the battery to increase.

key_points: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier
Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another

learning.explanation: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another. These units are used in situations where AC distribution system needs to supply a DC system. Batteries work with DC, therefore required the rectifier to convert from AC to DC, and the transformer to provide the correct voltage to charge the battery. The other answers are incorrect: “the AC bus via current limiters” – Current limiters will not change the power from AC to DC, therefore this is incorrect. “a static inverter” – Static inverters are used to convert DC into AC, therefore are not applicable for this scenario. “a DC transformer and rectifier” – A transformer will alter the voltage which could be required, however as mentioned above the rectifier converts AC into DC therefore is not applicable for this scenario.

key_points: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU)

Upon detection of a dangerous situation in the generator; which could be over-excitation or overvoltage; the GCU will open the exciter control relay which will protect the generator from potential further damage

learning.explanation: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU). Upon detection of a dangerous situation in the generator; which could be over-excitation or overvoltage; the GCU will open the exciter control relay which will protect the generator from potential further damage. At the same time, the GCU will also open the generator circuit breaker (GCB) to disconnect the generator from its bus bar. Should any other command be transmitted from the control panel (except the dog clutch release) it will necessarily pass through the GCU before being executed to the given system. All the modern GCUs can record and provide failure indications at any time.

options.A: House the battery in a vented metal casing.
options.B: Install a fuse on the positive pole of the battery.

com or in the exam feedback section of your dashboard, thanks! Housing lithium-ion batteries in a vented metal casing can help to prevent them from becoming a fire hazard by reducing the risk of thermal runaway, which is a condition in which the battery temperature increases rapidly, potentially leading to ignition
learning.explanation: Note: We have limited feedback about this question and it may be different in the exam. Please send us any further exam feedback in the comments, by email to info@atplquestions.com or in the exam feedback section of your dashboard, thanks! Housing lithium-ion batteries in a vented metal casing can help to prevent them from becoming a fire hazard by reducing the risk of thermal runaway, which is a condition in which the battery temperature increases rapidly, potentially leading to ignition. The vented casing allows for dissipation of heat and venting of any flammable gases that may be generated during thermal runaway. The other options listed are not effective in preventing lithium-ion batteries from becoming a fire hazard. Installing a fuse on the positive pole of the battery does not address the root cause of thermal runaway, and may not provide adequate protection against ignition. Placing a halon fire extinguisher in the compartment with the battery is not a proactive measure to prevent thermal runaway and may not be able to effectively extinguish a fire that has already started. Continuously charging the battery during flight also does not prevent thermal runaway, and may actually increase the risk of thermal runaway if the battery is overcharged or damaged in some way.

learning.explanation: When the voltage of the generator is greater than the battery’s voltage, the generator breaker will close in order to supply the batteries with current and charge them. However, when the opposite is true, the reverse current relay will open so that the batteries don’t ‘charge’ the generator. The battery charge limiters will control each battery’s contractor in order to ensure (among others) automatic battery connection for charging, protect them against thermal runaway and short-circuit, and prevent complete discharging when the aircraft is on the ground.

content.question: In the armature of an electric motor, torque is (1)_____ to current and (2)_____ to magnetic field strength.

options.A: (1) proportional; (2) proportional
options.B: (1) proportional; (2) inversely proportional

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.01: Describe how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current, and the resulting magnetic fields within the motor. The armature is the spinning section of an electric motor. The field coils produce an magnetic field similar to that of a permanent magnet, only stronger, and able to be changed. The armature is the spinning coil(s) of wire that interact with that magnetic field to produce rotational movement. When the electric current in the armature increases, this increases the interaction with the magnetic field and increases torque. Therefore, the current is directly proportional to the torque produced. The magnetic field produced by the field coils also affects the torque. The stronger the magnetic field, the greater the interaction with the current flowing through the armature, so the greater the torque produced. Therefore, the magnetic field strength is also directly proportional to the torque produced. Both these statements are the same, no matter how the motor is wound (in series or in parallel).

content.question: AC generators operated in parallel must have the same…

options.A: frequency and amperage.
options.B: amperage and kVAR.

key_points: AC generators (otherwise known as alternators) convert mechanical energy into an alternating current

When working in parallel and before connecting, alternators must have equal: Frequency: Damage can occur when there is a difference in frequency, as one generator tries to slow down and the other tries to speed up
Phase sequence: At any point in time, the phases of both generators must be identical (see graph)
learning.explanation: AC generators (otherwise known as alternators) convert mechanical energy into an alternating current. When working in parallel and before connecting, alternators must have equal: Frequency: Damage can occur when there is a difference in frequency, as one generator tries to slow down and the other tries to speed up. Phase sequence: At any point in time, the phases of both generators must be identical (see graph). Voltage: the voltage output of both generators must be equal before being paralleled. Therefore the correct answer is: “Voltage and phase” The other answers are incorrect: “voltage and amperage”: Even though equal voltage is required, the amperage is not required to be equal before paralleling. “amperage and kVAR”: Both the amperage and the kVAR (kilovolt-amperes reactive) are not required to be maintained equal during paralleling of alternators. “Frequency and amperage”: Even though the frequency is required to be constant, amperage is not, therefore this is incorrect.

content.question: What occurs during a DC generator's armature runaway?

options.A: Current decreases in the armature, but because it increases in the commutator, torque remains constant.
options.B: Current decreases in the armature, and because it also decreases in the commutator, torque is reduced.
options.C: Current increases in the armature, and since it also increases in the commutator, torque increases.
options.D: Current increases in the armature, but because it reduces in the commutator, torque is constant.

key_points: When a DC motor suddenly encounters a decrease in load, such as in a runaway situation, the resistance diminishes, causing the rotor (armature) speed to rise
However, this rapid increase in speed poses a risk of motor damage
Instead of converting into shaft rotation, the surplus energy generates heat
learning.explanation: When a DC motor suddenly encounters a decrease in load, such as in a runaway situation, the resistance diminishes, causing the rotor (armature) speed to rise. However, this rapid increase in speed poses a risk of motor damage. Instead of converting into shaft rotation, the surplus energy generates heat. As the mechanical load on the motor decreases, its speed increases, leading to a rise in back electromotive force (EMF). With a higher back EMF, the armature current decreases, thereby diminishing the torque applied to the motor. Torque, which represents the twisting force driving the motor, is measured in Newton-meters (Nm). It is influenced by the voltage, current, and magnetic fields within the motor. A decrease in current results in a reduction in the motor's torque output.

key_points: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit
They prevent the maximum power rating of a component to be exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating

learning.explanation: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit. They prevent the maximum power rating of a component to be exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating. Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit. There’re 3 types of fuses commonly used in electrical circuits: Cartridge fuse – tubular glass or ceramic body, 2 brass end caps and a tinned copper wire (or silver wire, or pure zinc). High rupture capacity (HRC) – designed for high current rated equipment. Current limiter fuse – high melting point fuses allowing them to carry a significant overload current before rupturing. All fuses have a current-specific rating (in amperes) that will indicate the maximum current they will be able to carry continuously or intermittently without excessively heating and rupturing. The rating of a fuse is designed so that it is not less than the current normally flowing in the circuit, but it ruptures just slightly below the safety limit of the equipment used. A fuse simply consists of a type of wire, as described above, that has a low melting point. As it is placed in series, the excessive electrical load will melt the wire and rupture the flow of current, should it be higher than the fuse’s ampere rating engraved upon it.

learning.explanation: There is no possible explanation for this question. There are no learning objectives that mention anything about computer life expectancy. Unfortunately, it isn't even strictly true either. Computer components do have a lifespan, and it is affected by temperature (higher temperatures are worse), but not between 30°C and 40°C. Depending on the component, the temperature operating windows for modern computer components are between 80°C and 120°C. Below this top end, a temperature change of 10°C would not half the lifespan of a component. In fact, modern computer components usually have very little variation between life expectancy at 80°C and at 30°C. Perhaps in older (a lot older) computers, this might be the case, but even then, I would be very sceptical that they would lose so much lifespan at such low temperatures unless 30°C is the maximum temperature for a particular component, where this could end up being true. That appears to be what EASA is saying though, a 10°C increase in temperature correlates to half the life expectancy. key_points: One of the biggest threats to Ni-Cd (Nickel Cadmium) and Lithium Ion Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway

The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating
Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly
learning.explanation: One of the biggest threats to Ni-Cd (Nickel Cadmium) and Lithium Ion Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway. The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating. Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly. It often happens due to overcharging/overheating and a combination of the two. Damage is also a massive factor in the thermal runaway of lithium ion batteries, as these have very high energy densities, so can suffer from very high currents if two different parts of the battery meet unexpectedly. I would not refer to that as thermal runaway, but it is incredibly dangerous, and we don't think EASA knows the difference. Furthermore, damage can reduce a battery's charging capacity and circuitry that limits current flow, which can subsequently lead to overcharging/overheating, causing a true thermal runaway. The worst case scenario in a thermal runaway is that a fire begins. Fire is pretty much the worst case scenario onboard any aircraft, other than complete structural failure perhaps, and lithium ion battery fires burn extremely hot. Ni-Cd fires are not as hot, but any fire is extremely bad, and these batteries are usually stored away from where people can contain the fires.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.08.02: Describe the following five basic logic functions, as used in aircraft FCOM documentation, and recognise their schematic symbols according to the ANSI/MIL standard: AND; OR; NOT; NOR; NAND. Logic gates are the building blocks of computer processing. Computers operate at the deepest level in binary, a series of transistors holding either a value of 1 or 0. Logic gates allow these 1s and 0s to be calculated, and these very simple functions can be combined and programmed at a much higher level that can then become computer programs. For our simple purposes, an integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output will result. The five basic logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted "AND" output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted "OR" output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question: If one of the 12 cells of a Lead-acid battery has a broken connection rendering it inoperable, the battery…

options.B: Has 1/12 less capacity but can still be used.
options.C: Has 1/12 less voltage but can still be used.

key_points: Batteries may be used as single cell or multiple cells
Multiple cells can be interconnected either in series or in parallel, depending on the desired voltage and capacity
In series connection, the positive terminal of one cell links to the negative terminal of the next, forming a chain
learning.explanation: Batteries may be used as single cell or multiple cells. Multiple cells can be interconnected either in series or in parallel, depending on the desired voltage and capacity. In series connection, the positive terminal of one cell links to the negative terminal of the next, forming a chain. The total voltage is the aggregate of individual cell voltages, while the capacity remains that of a single cell. In the case of series-connected cells with one cell rendered inoperative, the entire battery becomes nonfunctional. In parallel connection, the positive terminals are interconnected, as are the negative terminals. Here, the total voltage matches that of one cell, while the capacity is the cumulative sum of individual cell capacities. In Lead-acid batteries, each cell typically has a nominal voltage ranging from 2 to 2.2 V, while in NiCd batteries, it ranges from 1.2 to 1.25 V. To achieve desired output voltages such as 12 V or 24 V, these cells are connected in series.

content.question: A starter-generator is an electrical generator that…

options.A: creates a high energy impulse for the igniters during engine start.
options.B: uses an electric starter motor for start-up of its rotor.
options.C: generates electric power for the engine starter motor.
options.D: performs as an electric motor during engine start.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.03.01.04: Describe the basic operating principle of a starter generator and state its purpose. Motors and generators are very similar, both in concept and in design. A motor converts electrical energy into rotation, whilst a generator converts rotation into electrical energy. They both use induction to make this happen, and therefore look very similar. This means that we can actually use one item to do both tasks, and just change whether we give it electrical energy, or rotational (kinetic) energy. We can actually use them for either piston or turbine engines, but most questions do ask about them in the context of turbine engines. They can be either AC or DC, with the smaller engines using mostly DC and larger engines (such as those on the B787) using AC. When the aircraft is being started, the starter-generator acts as an electrical "starter" motor, allowing the engine to get up to sufficient speed for it to have self-sustaining RPM (or idling in a piston engine). As soon as this is complete, the electricity input into the starter-generator is removed, and the generator (being still attached the spinning engine) is now generating electricity through the induction of the spinning coils, inducing current. It started the aircraft by doing the job of a motor, but then changed job, and is a generator for the rest of the flight.

learning.explanation: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consist of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore, it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another. One problem appears after the rectification stage of this process as the output is fluctuating. This fluctuation makes the DC unusable for equipment use and it needs to be minimized. This is usually achieved by fitting a filter or smoothing circuit at the output of the rectifier. It is also required to maintain a constant DC supply at the exit of this filter, regardless of the load applied. Therefore, a sort of compensation needs to be fitted to overcome this problem and this solution is called stabilization.

learning.explanation: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU, or CSD. The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred to as speed. In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current. The output of the hydraulic motor, and therefore the speed of the motor is dictated by the angle of the swashplate. The angle of the swash plate will either limit or increase the oil flow towards the hydraulic and in turn affect the rpm of the engine. The angle of the swash plate is controlled by the speed governor, which in turn is controlled by the load controller. The load controller senses the output frequency of the alternator and will adjust the swash plate accordingly to increase or decrease the torque output to the generator. The CSD can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft at any time during the flight. However, only the engineers can reconnect the CSD, on the ground, with the engines off.

content.question: In order that DC generators will achieve equal load sharing when operating in parallel, it is necessary to ensure that…

options.A: equal loads are connected to each generator busbar before paralleling.
options.B: their voltages are almost equal.
options.D: the synchronising bus-bar is disconnected from the busbar system.

key_points: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar
This allows the load to be shared between the two generators, and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing
When running the generators, it is necessary for each generator to provide half of the current required by the bas bar
learning.explanation: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar. This allows the load to be shared between the two generators, and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing. When running the generators, it is necessary for each generator to provide half of the current required by the bas bar. In that scenario, they are load sharing. However to achieve load sharing the voltage output of both generators must be identical. If the voltage output of one generator was to exceed the other, then the current would flow towards the lower voltage generator. The scenario where the current flows from the generator with the higher voltage to the generator with the lower voltage output is known as recirculating current. In this case the higher voltage generator will be providing the current of the bus bar, and also the current demanded by the lower voltage generator. The reverse flow of the current to the generator will turn the lower voltage generator into a motor turning in the opposite direction of the rotation of the engine. Clearly this is a very undesirable situation therefore parallel systems have reverse current relays installs to prevent the reverse flow from occurring. Therefore the correct answer is that: In order for two generators to effectively load share in a parallel system, it is necessary to ensure that “their voltages are almost equal”. The other answers are incorrect because: “Equal loads are connected to each generator busbar before paralleling” Both generators supply the same busbar for there to be load sharing, therefore if they are supplying a load to the busbar they are already parallel. “Adequate voltage exists” As explained above, for there to be equal load sharing both generators must have the same voltage output, otherwise recirculating current will occur. Therefore this is incorrect. “The synchronizing bus-bar is disconnected from the busbar system” Each generator is first made to run at the correct voltage before closing its generator line contactor, therefore connecting to the busbar. This statement is therefore incorrect.

content.question: What is the name of a switch operated by a bimetallic strip?

options.A: Circuit breaker
options.B: Magnetic relay

key_points: This question is slightly vague, but appears to be describing a thermal circuit breaker, as explained below

The other option "thermal switch" is a little troubling as in a very literal sense, you could argue it to be somewhat correct, however, that is not how we would usually refer to a device like this, and it is not a phrase we should know or use for this subject, so we are saying it is incorrect
Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts)
learning.explanation: This question is slightly vague, but appears to be describing a thermal circuit breaker, as explained below. The other option "thermal switch" is a little troubling as in a very literal sense, you could argue it to be somewhat correct, however, that is not how we would usually refer to a device like this, and it is not a phrase we should know or use for this subject, so we are saying it is incorrect. Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high for too long, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit, exactly like operating a switch. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, which is good for some systems but not for others. The higher the overcurrent, the faster the thermal CB will trip. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch (solenoid) to trip the breaker almost instantly. Obviously, it cannot be absolutely instant, as things take time to move and therefore a very short overcurrent will still be experienced by the circuit, so we have said that "trips almost immediately" is correct.

content.question: An important design feature of circuit breakers is that they...

options.A: can withstand the temporary overcurrent that occurs when switching on large consumers such as electric heating.
options.B: cut the circuit immediately in case any overcurrent occurs.
options.C: cannot be used in circuits where temporary, short-time overcurrent may occur, such as when switching on large consumers (e.g., electric motors).
options.D: can withstand temporary, short-time overcurrents that occur when switching on large consumers such as electric motors.

key_points: NOTE: This question is quite similar to Q215915
This question is quite narrow minded, as many different types of circuit breaker exist, some of which are designed to handle transient load spikes, etc
We using best judgement here and knowledge of other similar exam questions to answer this one
learning.explanation: NOTE: This question is quite similar to Q215915. This question is quite narrow minded, as many different types of circuit breaker exist, some of which are designed to handle transient load spikes, etc. We using best judgement here and knowledge of other similar exam questions to answer this one. Please let us know if you see either question in the exam so we can verify them, thank you! When switching on an electric motor, there is an initial inrush current that is several times the motor's full load current. This is due to the high initial torque required to overcome the motor's inertia and start the rotation. This inrush current can cause a transient overcurrent that may exceed the rated current of the circuit breaker. Their circuit breakers are often built to handle these very short term overcurrents, but would trip if the overcurrent was sustained. Other heavy electrical consumers such as heating elements, ignition boxes, and strobe lights (intermittent loads) do not have the same inrush current as electric motors, and their startup transient spikes are not as severe. In that case, they may be fitted with circuit breakers with less ability to handle transient loads. Therefore, the design and rating of circuit breakers depend on various factors such as the type of load, application, and any other specific requirements. Therefore, the selection of the appropriate circuit breaker must consider the nature of the load and the operating conditions to ensure proper protection and reliable operation.

content.question: Assuming that the APU is unserviceable, after a failure of both AC generators, a RAT (Ram Air Turbine), if fitted, will be able to provide power for...

options.A: the batteries.
options.B: the AC emergency bus.

key_points: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies
In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment
The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump
learning.explanation: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies. In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment. The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump. Consequently, more power is generated when the aircraft is operating at a higher speed and less is generated when operating at lower speeds. For this question we have based our explanation off the Airbus A320, as is often the reference aircraft for EASA (sometimes they also use the B737 as a reference, but it does not have a RAT). The A320 has 3 main AC generators (one per engine and one for the APU), but if all of these fail (whilst airborne), then the RAT will deploy, and once spun up, it will pressurise the blue hydraulic system using a hydraulic pump. This system then drives a hydraulic motor which spins up the emergency AC generator. The emergency AC generator provides power to the AC ESS and (via the ESS TR unit) the DC ESS bus bars, in other words, essential AC and DC services. Therefore, essential AC services is the most correct answer here. As a side note, if this were to fail also, then the batteries would then be used to feed the DC essential services and (via a static inverter) the AC essential services, but would have a limited duration, of course. The AC emergency bus is not the correct answer as often this is not the name of such a bus bar and also, it also doesn't actually describe what services are being fed.

content.question:
What will happen if the rotor of a DC electrical motor seizes?
The current in the stator (1) _____, the current in the rotor (2) _____, and the torque (3) _____.

options.A: (1) decreases, (2) decreases, (3) decreases
options.B: (1) decreases, (2) decreases, (3) increases

key_points: Inside an electrical motor, when the rotor seizes, it is a similar process to putting a very large load on the motor
If this occurs, then all of a sudden, the motor is not cutting any lines of flux (moving through the magnetic field), which means that the "back EMF" is removed completely
This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical energy due to it being turned into kinetic energy inside the motor
learning.explanation: Inside an electrical motor, when the rotor seizes, it is a similar process to putting a very large load on the motor. If this occurs, then all of a sudden, the motor is not cutting any lines of flux (moving through the magnetic field), which means that the "back EMF" is removed completely. This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical energy due to it being turned into kinetic energy inside the motor. (Lenz's Law) If this back EMF (resistive force) is removed, that means that for the same voltage, the current can flow much more easily, so the current will increase through the armature, sometimes by a very large amount. This can be enough to melt fuses or wires in some motors. With an increased current, the available force from the motor per turn (which are no longer occuring) will also increase, and this is known as the torque. The seizure therefore creates higher torque, similar to when a motor is intially started up. We then have to consider what happens to the current within the stator, known as the field coils, which produce the magnetic field that the rotor turns within. The current through the stator will also increase when the rotor seizes, so would have a more powerful magnetic field. This helps towards the higher torque. (This question assumes that series windings are used, it being the most common in DC motors by far). Note: The feedback on this question is not perfect. If anyone has exam feedback on this question, they can be sent to info@atplquestions.com or placed in the comments, thank you!

content.question: What is a major risk to a battery in case of damage or abuse?

options.A: High current and thermal runaway.
options.B: Low current and thermal runaway.

key_points: When a battery undergoes damage or abuse, such as physical trauma or exposure to extreme conditions, it can lead to a situation called thermal runaway
Thermal runaway occurs when the battery's internal temperature rises rapidly which triggers the sudden release of stored energy, potentially leading to self-ignition, explosions, and fires
Thermal runaway may occur due to factors like overcharging, short circuits, or external heat sources
learning.explanation: When a battery undergoes damage or abuse, such as physical trauma or exposure to extreme conditions, it can lead to a situation called thermal runaway. Thermal runaway occurs when the battery's internal temperature rises rapidly which triggers the sudden release of stored energy, potentially leading to self-ignition, explosions, and fires. Thermal runaway may occur due to factors like overcharging, short circuits, or external heat sources. High current, often caused by these abusive conditions, exacerbates thermal runaway by increasing the rate of temperature rise within the battery. As the temperature climbs, it can trigger a chain reaction within the battery cells, leading to the release of more energy and generating even higher temperatures. This cycle can escalate quickly and result in the battery overheating, swelling, leaking, or even catching fire or exploding. Note: The primary threat posed by Li-ion batteries is thermal runaway.

Basically, an AC generator has to be capable of producing more power, apparent power, than is actually used in real terms. Units of apparent power are in VA or kVA, while those of real power are in kW. kVA have to do with voltage regulation and field strengths. A generator is usually rated in a value of kVA, and occasionally in a value of kW. A WATT/NAR (VAR) meter is located on the flight deck of some aircraft, and by selection indicates the relevant reading on a generator. In simple words, the measured output power components of a constant frequency AC system are kW, kVA and kVAR.

400 Hz
learning.explanation: Nowadays, commercial aircraft electrical system is supplied by two (or more) engine-driven generators regulated in speed by integrated drives. These generators’ characteristics are: 115/200 Volts, 3-phase AC. 400 Hz. 90 kVA. 28 V DC is obtained by converting the generators’ output AC via the transformer rectifier units. The APU generator is essentially the same as the main engine-driven generators, so it will provide exactly the same output. The APU will electrically supply the aircraft and other associated systems on the ground when the engines are not running, and the Ground Power unit (GPU) is not connected. As to why nowadays commercial aircraft generators are integrated with a CSD in an IDGU (integrated drive generator unit) and use mainly 400 Hz AC is because a higher frequency allows the manufacturers to make smaller and lighter generators that would allow increasing the payload instead of carrying extra weight from the generators. Because the frequency of an AC generator mainly relies on the number of pairs of poles and the speed of the rotor, it is sufficient to increase the generator’s rotational speed in order to provide a higher frequency, and thus decrease the generator’s size appropriately.

content.question: What is the worst case scenario if thermal runaway occurs?

options.A: Fire.
options.B: Engine failure.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.02.01.10: Describe how to contain a battery thermal runaway highlighting the following: how one cell can affect the neighbouring cells; challenges if it happens in an aircraft during flight. One of the biggest threats to Ni-Cd (Nickel Cadmium) and Lithium Ion Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway. The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating. Lithium Ion batteries are more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly. It often happens due to overcharging/overheating and a combination of the two. The worst case scenario is that a fire begins. Fire is pretty much the worst case scenario onboard any aircraft, other than complete structural failure perhaps, and lithium ion battery fires burn extremely hot. Ni-Cd fires are not as hot, but any fire is extremely bad, and these batteries are usually stored away from where people can contain the fires. Electrical failure could happen also, as the battery will become unusable as part of this process, and it could do significant damage to the electrical system eventually, but that is still not nearly as bad as any sort of fire.

content.question: To ensure correct load sharing between AC generators operating in parallel…

options.A: only reactive loads need to be matched.
options.B: only real loads need to be matched.
options.C: both real and reactive loads must be matched.
options.D: the matching of loads is unimportant.

key_points: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar
This allows the load to be shared between the two generators and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing
Both real and reactive loads must be matched to ensure correct load sharing between AC generators operating in parallel
learning.explanation: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar. This allows the load to be shared between the two generators and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing. Both real and reactive loads must be matched to ensure correct load sharing between AC generators operating in parallel. When they are connected in parallel, the reactive loads are balanced by regulating the energizing current (exciter field current). On the other side, real load sharing is achieved by increasing the torque input to the lower speed alternator and vice versa. Real Loads – actual working load directly related to the mechanical power (torque) supplied to the alternator (the engine or the CSDU). It is called “real” because it is dependent on the torque at its output shaft available for supplying the aircraft’s electrical equipment. Reactive Loads – vector sum of inductive and capacitive currents and voltages (in KVAR).
