options.B: is DC and is fed directly to the field windings of the rotor poles through contacts and slip rings.
options.C: comes from an additional, smaller DC generator installed on the end of the alternator.
options.D: is AC and is being fed directly to the field windings to the rotor poles through contacts and slip rings.

key_points: Note: This is a difficult question, and there are two answers that could be considered mostly correct, but neither being fully correct
Our most recent feedback gives us the current correct answer, but the other one could be easily argued, dependent on the wording in the real exam
Please let us know if you get this question in the real exam, and differences you can remember, and if you know what the correct answer was, thank you! Learning Objectives 021
learning.explanation: Note: This is a difficult question, and there are two answers that could be considered mostly correct, but neither being fully correct. Our most recent feedback gives us the current correct answer, but the other one could be easily argued, dependent on the wording in the real exam. Please let us know if you get this question in the real exam, and differences you can remember, and if you know what the correct answer was, thank you! Learning Objectives 021.09.03.00 Generation. Remark: For standardisation purposes, the following standard expressions are used: DC generator: produces DC output; DC alternator: produces AC, rectified by integrated rectifying unit, the output is DC; DC alternator: producing a DC output by using a rectifier; AC generator: produces AC output; Starter generator: integrated combination of a generator and a starter motor; Permanent magnet alternator/ generator: self-exciting AC generator. You can read the full explanation of a brushless AC alternator/generator below, but specific to this question, the rotating field coils for the main generator get their DC current from another generator on the same shaft, which is then rectified from AC to DC by a spinning rectifier on that shaft (EASA would refer to this arrangement as a DC alternator, not a DC generator). The exciter generator gets its (DC) magnetic field from the voltage regulator, which usually receives its electricity from the final 3 phase output of the whole system, but initially gets its energy from a permanent magnet generator, with the magnets mounted on the same shaft, and producing unregulated voltage output just to start the system going. The system is completely brushless, which means that the only method of transferring electricity from a spinning component to a rotating component is without physical contact, so no brushes, slip rings, carbon contacts, etc. That removes 2 answers immediately. For the other two possible options: Permanent Magnet Generator: This answer is the most recent feedback, and is partially correct, but is usually just used for the initial excitation current. Smaller DC generator on the end of the alternator: This could also be correct, particularly if it said DC alternator, as that is effectively what the exciter and bridge rectifier are acting as. Brushless AC Alternators (PMG Type) Modern aircraft AC generators are predominantly self-exciting brushless alternators, and often incorporate a permanent magnet generator. To explain this, we are going to work backwards, from what we want our final output to be, to how we get every component of that to work. A generator is made up of a magnetic field (either produced by permanent magnets or by an electric "field" coil which acts like a magnet) and an armature coil. One of those is spinning (rotor) and the other is stationary (stator), and which is which is decided by the input and outputs required. The armature is where AC power is generated, from the rotational energy inputted by the spinning shaft (often from an engine via constant speed drive). The basis of an AC alternator/generator (for AC output they mean the same thing) is that we wish to have the output armature windings on the stator of the main generator, so we can send the AC power straight to the bus bars. This means that the field windings on the main generator must be mounter to the rotor. This main generator is where we make the power to output to the aircraft distribution system. The voltage of the main generator is regulated by changing the strength of the magnetic field, which just means changing the voltage through the field coil. So we somehow need a way to feed voltage-regulated DC power to a spinning coil rotating at 400 Hz. We do this by having a second generator, the exciter generator, mounted on the same shaft, with the rotor this time being the armature coils (and the stator is therefore the magnetic field producer). The spinning armatures generate 3 phase AC current which is sent through a spinning rectifier to produce the field coil for the main generator. The magnetic field for the exciter generator is provided by a DC supply from the voltage regulator. If the voltage output of the main generator drops, the voltage regulator increases the voltage to the exciter field coil, and the voltage of the main generator field will increase, increasing the final output voltage. Initial excitement can be provided by a permanent magnet generator, a third generator on the same shaft, this time with a permanent magnet (field) mounted on the rotor, and the armature (stator) picking up an AC supply, then rectifying it and using it to power the exciter field or the voltage regulator, etc. When the shaft begins spinning, this will be the first thing to produce any current.

content.question: An aircraft has 4 engine driven generators and a split bus AC distribution system. Which of the following statements is true if no failures occur in flight?

options.A: Each pair of generators is connected to a common AC bus.
options.B: All 4 generators are connected to a common AC bus.
options.C: The AC buses are connected with bus-tie breakers.
options.D: Each generator is connected to its own dedicated AC bus bar.

key_points: Most modern aircraft with a twin engine design use a split bus system (rather than a parallel bus system), which differ in their distribution slightly
Split bus systems have a left AC bus and a right AC bus, and are fed solely by the single engine generator on that side
There is no connection between the two buses (in normal operation) as that would require the generators to be "paralleled" to each other, which means extra complexity
learning.explanation: Most modern aircraft with a twin engine design use a split bus system (rather than a parallel bus system), which differ in their distribution slightly. Split bus systems have a left AC bus and a right AC bus, and are fed solely by the single engine generator on that side. There is no connection between the two buses (in normal operation) as that would require the generators to be "paralleled" to each other, which means extra complexity. Parallel bus systems, on the other hand, are more useful when 3 or 4 engined aircraft are used, as each generator has its own AC bus bar to feed the aircraft electrical loads, but the generators are all paralleled to each other and there is a synchronising bus bar connecting all of the individual circuits. This is more useful for load sharing in the event of a generator failure, and general load sharing for unbalanced systems, meaning each generator produces the same load under normal operation. It does mean that some or all generators do have to be paralleled though, which is a bit of added complexity, matching their frequency, voltage and phase. That complexity is removed in the split bus system. Having a 4 engine-generator aircraft with a split bus system is still perfectly doable, but there are a few different ways it can be implemented, in terms of which bus bars get tied together in the event of a failure. "Each pair of generators is connected to a common AC bus." This would require two generators to be paralleled on each side, which is sometimes called a partial parallel system (I believe the 747 has this), and is not a split bus system "All 4 generators are connected to a common AC bus." This is a completely parallel bus system, not split bus. "The AC buses are connected with bus-tie breakers." This is what happens in a split-bus system when a failure occurs, the failed generator is isolated from its bus bar, and the bus bar is then connected to a neighbouring bus bar to use it's electricity. This is not the case in normal operation. "Each generator is connected to its own dedicated AC bus bar." Yes, as mentioned above, in the split bus system, each generator solely feeds its own AC bus bar in normal operation (maybe two if there is a generator failure somewhere else).

content.question: What is the symbol commonly used for voltage?

learning.explanation: 021.09.01.02.04: Define voltage and current, and state their unit of measurement. Voltage, represented by "U" or "V", represents the potential difference between two points in an electrical circuit or system. This potential difference is what drives the flow of electric charge, typically represented by current (symbolized by "I"). Voltage is measured in volts, and it indicates the amount of electrical potential energy per unit charge available to do work in a circuit. Voltage (U) = Resistance (R) × Current (I) (commonly used for example in Germany, Poland, France) Voltage (V) = Resistance (R) × current (I) (commonly used for example in the UK, USA) For example, when you plug in an electrical device, such as a lamp, into a power outlet, the voltage difference between the two prongs of the outlet creates an electric field that drives the flow of electrons through the lamp, causing it to light up. This voltage difference is what provides the energy necessary for the lamp to function.

options.B: Transformer Rectifier Unit

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.03.04.02: State the function of a TRU and its purpose, including type of output. Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) combine both a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore, they convert Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) and also transform a certain voltage into another voltage. First, the transformation of voltage occurs whilst the current is in its AC state, then the unit gets to work turning the alternating current (which travels backwards and forwards within the circuit), into direct current which only flows one way. One problem then appears after this rectification stage as the output is now all in one direction, but is fluctuating. This fluctuation makes the direct current unusable. To make it a constant current, a filter, or smoothing circuit is used just before the output of the rectifier. This current should be made to remain the same, regardless of the load applied. Therefore, a sort of compensation needs to be fitted to overcome this problem and such a solution is called stabilisation.

content.question:
Which of the following statements correctly describes the operating principles of thermal and magnetic circuit breakers?
1. A thermal circuit breaker trips immediately when a high current is detected, using a magnetic mechanism to separate the contacts.
2. A magnetic circuit breaker uses a bimetallic strip that bends in response to excessive heat generated by prolonged overcurrent, causing it to trip after a short delay.
3. A thermal circuit breaker uses a bimetallic strip that bends due to heat from excessive current flow, typically causing a delayed trip, depending on the severity of the overcurrent.
4. A magnetic circuit breaker trips almost immediately when excessive current flows through it, due to a magnetic field created by the current, without any delay mechanism.

options.A: 1, 2 and 3
options.B: 2 and 4

key_points: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts)
The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs
The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together
learning.explanation: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high for too long, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, which is good for some systems but not for others. The higher the overcurrent, the faster the thermal CB will trip. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch (solenoid) to trip the breaker almost instantly. Obviously, it cannot be absolutely instant, as things take time to move and therefore a very short overcurrent will still be experienced by the circuit, so we have said that "trips almost immediately" is correct. Note that we still require further feedback to confirm how the question was laid out, and what correct answer the examiner has chosen (the use of "almost immediately" is not exact and they could take a different view), thank you.

content.question: The flight crew must be notified if a large amount of lithium batteries are being carried in cargo compartments, as these batteries...

options.A: explode when the cabin altitude is too high because of the differential pressure.
options.B: freeze at low temperatures, causing cracks in their metal casing.

key_points: A large threat to Lithium Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway

The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating
Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly
learning.explanation: A large threat to Lithium Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway. The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating. Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly. It often happens due to overcharging/overheating and a combination of the two. Damage is also a massive factor in the thermal runaway of lithium ion batteries, as these have very high energy densities, so can suffer from very high currents if two different parts of the battery meet unexpectedly. This is called an internal short circuit. It can cause a chain reaction (increased heat - increased resistance - increased heat, etc) and is incredibly dangerous. Furthermore, a lower amount of damage can reduce a battery's charging capacity and circuitry that limits current flow, which can subsequently lead to overcharging/overheating, causing a thermal runaway during charging. The worst case scenario with a damaged battery is that a fire begins. Fire is pretty much the worst case scenario onboard any aircraft, other than complete structural failure perhaps, and lithium ion battery fires burn extremely hot, in the thousands of degrees Celsius.

learning.explanation: Note: We have received conflicting feedback about which answer is correct. As the wording for both potential answers is not perfect, we are requesting any exam feedback that people have about this one, both the wording of the options and the correct answer. The other answer that we have feedback for is B: "the busbar will be switched to another busbar", which has a bad wording, but could be referring to "connecting" the two busbars together. Most modern aircraft with a twin engine design use a split bus system (rather than a parallel bus system), which differ in their distribution slightly. Split bus systems have a left AC bus and a right AC bus, and are fed solely by the engine generator on that side. There is no connection between the two busses (in normal operation) as that would require the generators to be "paralleled" to each other, which means extra complexity. This means that, if one generator fails, say the right generator for example, the right AC bus bar (and the right DC bus bar in most systems) would have no available power. This is when the generator circuit breaker (GCB) for the right generator would open, isolating the failed generator, and the bus tie breakers (BTBs) between the left and right AC busses would close, allowing the right AC bus to be fed from the left generator, via the left AC bus. This is just "connecting" the bus bars together. So far, this has all happened automatically, and the scenario is now stable, so the pilots can run checklists and decide what to do next. The left generator will be working hard at this point to feed all the onboard electricity, so the pilots would decide to start the APU (if it is available), and the right AC bus would likely be fed directly by the APU, and one of the BTBs opened to isolate the two AC busses from each other again.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct about an electrical fuse?

options.A: Upon reaching its nominal amperage, the fuse instantly melts.
options.B: Upon reaching its rated amperage, the fuse instantly melts.
options.C: The fuse must be as close as possible to the source to protect against short circuits.
options.D: The fuse provides protection against voltage exceedances.

key_points: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit
They prevent the maximum power rating of a component or wire from being exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating
Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit
learning.explanation: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit. They prevent the maximum power rating of a component or wire from being exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating. Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit. There’re 3 types of fuses commonly used in electrical circuits: Cartridge fuse – tubular glass or ceramic body, 2 brass end caps and a tinned copper wire (or silver wire, or pure zinc). High Rupture Capacity (HRC) – designed for high current rated equipment. Current limiter fuse – high melting point fuses allowing them to carry a significant overload current before rupturing. All fuses have a current-specific rating (in amperes) that will indicate the maximum current they will be able to carry continuously or intermittently without excessively heating and rupturing. The rating of a fuse is designed so that it is not less than the current normally flowing in the circuit, but it ruptures just slightly below the safety limit of the equipment used. A fuse simply consists of a type of wire, as described above, that has a low melting point. As it is placed in series, the excessive electrical load will melt the wire and rupture the flow of current, should it be higher than the fuse’s ampere rating engraved upon it. We can now go through the options: "Upon reaching its nominal amperage, the fuse instantly melts." Incorrect. A fuse's "nominal amperage" is an amperage that it is able to handle continuously with no problem, as nominal operations are completely expected. "Upon reaching its rated amperage, the fuse instantly melts." Incorrect. The rated amperage of a fuse is the maximum current they will be able to carry continuously or intermittently without excessively heating and rupturing. Therefore, it should not melt at this amperage. "The fuse must be as close as possible to the source to protect against short circuits." Correct. Whilst it may stray from the learning objectives a little, this option is correct as fuses are made to protect circuits from overcurrent, and therefore we wish to protect as much as possible of each circuit from overcurrent, particularly in the event of a short circuit, as they can happen anywhere on a wire or in a component and fry the source, wires or other components in the circuit. "The fuse provides protection against voltage exceedances." Incorrect. Fuses protect from overcurrent, not voltage exceedances.

key_points: A differential fault exists when there is a difference between the generator output current and the bus bar input current, which suggests that there is an earth fault between the two
The generator is essentially the powerhouse that creates electricity
This electricity is then channeled to a busbar, which acts like a central hub connecting different electrical circuits
learning.explanation: A differential fault exists when there is a difference between the generator output current and the bus bar input current, which suggests that there is an earth fault between the two. The generator is essentially the powerhouse that creates electricity. This electricity is then channeled to a busbar, which acts like a central hub connecting different electrical circuits. Think of the busbar as a meeting point where electricity from the generator is distributed to various parts of a system. When there's a big difference in the electrical characteristics (like current, voltage, or frequency) between the generator and the busbar, it's a sign that something might be wrong. This difference can indicate issues within the generator itself or in the wiring that connects it to the busbar. A differential fault specifically refers to this significant mismatch. It's a critical issue because it can lead to malfunctions or damage in the electrical system. To detect these faults, a special device called a differential relay is used. This relay constantly monitors the balance between the generator and the busbar. When it detects a large discrepancy, it triggers protective measures to prevent further damage or system failure.

content.question:
You are flying a twin-engined aircraft with an AC electrical system fed by two engine driven generators when one generator has a complete failure. Which of the following statements is correct in reference to the subsequent power distribution.
1. In an AC electrical system with a split-bus design, the load from the failed generator is automatically taken over by the remaining generator through the automatic AC bus-transfer function
2. In an AC electrical system with a parallel bus design, the load from the failed generator is directly taken over by the aircraft's battery providing DC electrical power to the bus

options.A: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Figure 1 is a split bus system, Figure 2 is parallel bus system
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Figure 1 is a split bus system, Figure 2 is parallel bus system. Learning Objective 021.09.04.03.02: Describe the following distribution consequences: power transfer between different power supplies; power transfer in the event of a supply failure; loss of all normal AC supplies. The two primary methods of distributing AC power in an aircraft are via the split bus and parallel bus systems. Split bus systems have each generator feeding its own load bus, which are not usually connected at all. They run independently of each other, and usually have a TRU (Transformer Rectifier Unit) each to provide DC electrical power. Parallel bus systems are naturally "paralleled" when possible, and have a synchronising bus (or sometimes 2) which means that many generators are all putting power into all the load busses. This system is most commonly used on aircraft with more than 2 engines, for simplicity. In the event of a generator failure in a split bus system, the generator is cut off from its load bus and the BTB (Bus Tie Breaker) is closed to allow the working generator to feed both load busses. The APU can then be used to take over the failed generator and return the system back to normal if it is available. As this happens after generator cut-off, there is no need to parallel the supplies in normal service. In a parallel bus system, a generator failure means that the failed generator will be cut off from the rest of the system, and the load busses will all be fed from the remaining generators that are already connected to it, so essentially the bus tie breaker is already closed, and the generator just needs to be disconnected via the GCB (Generator Circuit Breaker). The batteries provide DC power, which can be put through an inverter to feed the essential AC bus, but this would only occur in the event of a multiple generator failure, where the batteries are the only remaining power source.

options.B: To convert DC power into AC power at a different (usually higher) voltage.

key_points: Electricity can be transmitted through wires in two different ways, via Direct Current (DC) or Alternating Current (AC)
Direct current is the simplest to consider, charge flows from high potential to low potential (conventional) through electrical conductors continuously, all in the same direction

Alternating current is a little more complex, where the charge flows backwards and forwards through an electrical conductor, with the current increasing in one direction, then in the opposite direction, and so on
learning.explanation: Electricity can be transmitted through wires in two different ways, via Direct Current (DC) or Alternating Current (AC). Direct current is the simplest to consider, charge flows from high potential to low potential (conventional) through electrical conductors continuously, all in the same direction. Alternating current is a little more complex, where the charge flows backwards and forwards through an electrical conductor, with the current increasing in one direction, then in the opposite direction, and so on. The majority of light aircraft simply use a DC electrical system (often 14 V or 28 V), as this is usually the simplest to generate and distribute through a simple aircraft with few consumers. Larger aircraft use AC systems (often 3 phase, 115 V, 400 Hz) as they require increased power generation and have consumers require high loads. They also have some loads onboard that require DC power, so have this capability also. Electricity can be transferred between the two different types (AC and DC) by the use of rectifiers and inverters. AC is "rectified" to turn it into DC (think of it that AC is too complex, and it has to be fixed ["rectified"] to turn it into simple direct current). In aircraft, we do not want to turn 115 V AC straight into DC, it would be far too much for the 28 V circuits, so first a transformer is used to bring the voltage down to 28 V, and then it is rectified. Aircraft use an integrated Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) for these job, to go from high voltage AC to lower voltage DC. DC can be "inverted" into alternating current, and this is quite intuitive, as AC is just DC, flipped backwards and forwards many times per second, and then smoothed into a sine wave. Aircraft will often have an inverter on board, for operations where the aircraft needs to use a DC power source like batteries to power it's AC consumers. As with the rectification process, the low voltage DC will create low voltage AC, which will need to go through a step-up transformer to reach the usual 115 V AC required.

If the magnitude and direction of the overcurrent is sufficient to heat the wire to a temperature that ignites surrounding combustibles, the overcurrent would cause a fire
Possible causes for overcurrent include: short circuits, excessive load, and incorrect design

If the magnitude and direction of the overcurrent is sufficient to heat the wire to a temperature that ignites surrounding combustibles, the overcurrent would cause a fire. Possible causes for overcurrent include: short circuits, excessive load, and incorrect design.

content.question: In an AC circuit with a capacitor, voltage is kept the same, but the AC frequency is increased. What will happen to the current?

options.A: Current reduces down to a value of zero.
options.B: current increases.

key_points: This is quite a complex question to be asked at ATPL level, especially as it was removed from the learning objectives when changing over to the new syllabus (Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: This is quite a complex question to be asked at ATPL level, especially as it was removed from the learning objectives when changing over to the new syllabus (Learning Objective 021.09.01.04). It should therefore be appealed if seen in the exam. Please let us know if you get this in the exam. We do not think you should see it, but cannot be 100% sure that it has been removed. Nonetheless, if you do see this in the exam, you can still answer correctly of course. A capacitor is a form of short-term electrical storage device, which stores a small amount charge on one side of the capacitor, which can be rapidly gained or lost. They are used in disposable cameras to produce the flash (they have thousands of other uses, but this is one of the most easily understood). In an AC circuit, though, capacitors cause the current to shift in relation to the voltage. The current leads the voltage, by up to 90º phase difference. There is a mechanic that drives this, but we do not need to know it (we actually should not need to know any of this on the current syllabus). The difference between voltage and current causes a reduction in power called capacitive reactance, which causes inefficiency in the circuit. The effect of capacitive reactance reduces at higher frequencies (the alternating current alternates more times per second), and this allows the current to increase at these higher frequencies. theoretically, at infinite frequency, the capacitive reactance would have no effect, and the AC circuit would act as if no capacitor were present at all. Therefore, an increase in frequency causes an increase in current for the same voltage.

options.A: To properly insulate each wire from the others in the bundle.
options.B: To allow wires to be labelled for quicker maintenance.
options.C: To physically strengthen the bundle of wires.
options.D: To eliminate electromagnetic induction interfering with other wires in the bundle.

key_points: Current flowing through a wire changes the nearby electric field, and causes weak, unwanted electromagnetic signals to be produced from the wire when the current changes
This can affect the current flow through other nearby conductors, particularly nearby wires, which causes electromagnetic interference (EMI)
Electrical shielding is where a wire is surrounded by a material that either blocks the EMI, or even conducts it to ground
learning.explanation: Current flowing through a wire changes the nearby electric field, and causes weak, unwanted electromagnetic signals to be produced from the wire when the current changes. This can affect the current flow through other nearby conductors, particularly nearby wires, which causes electromagnetic interference (EMI). Electrical shielding is where a wire is surrounded by a material that either blocks the EMI, or even conducts it to ground. This stops the interference on nearby wires, and it also works to suppress a wire's EMI to within its own shielding, so it does not affect other wires in a bundle. It is important to remember that shielding is not the same as insulation.

learning.explanation: Here you see that the two left gates are OR Gates and the one on the right is an AND Gate. The OR Gate will pass the signal trough when; either one or both sensors detect smoke. The AND Gate will only give an alert when both input give a positive signal. Concluding, the AND Gate will need both OR Gates to give a positive signal. Therefore: “When only the C1 and C3 sensors detect smoke” is incorrect because When only C1 and C3 detect smoke the bottom OR Gate will not give a positive signal. “Only when all sensor detect smoke” is incorrect because of the word: “Only” “When the C1 and C2 sensors detect smoke” is correct because when C1 and C2 detect smoke, both OR Gates will give a positive signal resulting in the AND Gate to give an alert “When only one sensor detects smoke” is incorrect because with only one smoke detector detecting smoke there will be only 1 OR Gate with a positive signal and this will not make the AND Gate give an alert.

content.question: In an aircraft fitted with a constant frequency AC power supply, DC power is obtained from a…

options.A: transformer rectifier unit (TRU).
options.B: static inverter.

key_points: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier
Therefore, it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another
One problem appears after the rectification stage of this process as the output is fluctuating
learning.explanation: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore, it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another. One problem appears after the rectification stage of this process as the output is fluctuating. This fluctuation makes the DC unusable for equipment use and it needs to be minimized. This is usually achieved by fitting a filter, or smoothing circuit at the output of the rectifier. It is also required to maintain a constant DC supply at the exit of this filter, regardless of the load applied. Therefore, a sort of compensation needs to be fitted to overcome this problem and this solution is called stabilization.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.02.01.08: State that in the case of loss of all generated power (battery power only) the remaining electrical power is time-limited. When an aircraft does run out of working generators, it is a very high risk scenario. The onboard batteries are powerful enough to feed the essential and emergency DC and AC busses, via an inverter (as batteries only produce DC), but they only have a limited amount of charge stored. The batteries should be usable for 30 minutes running essential and emergency (vital) systems from a fully charged state. This is the reason that most aircraft are not allowed to fly with only 1 working generator, because if that fails, the aircraft is in the high risk situation described above.

content.question:
Which of these statements about frequency are correct/incorrect?
1. The SI unit for frequency is revolutions per minute (RPM)
2. Frequency is defined as a number of cycles per unit of time

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.03.04: Define frequency and state the unit of measurement. Frequency is the amount of times something happens over a particular unit of time. It is also used a lot in the study of electrics, as frequency measures the number of cycles that occur per unit time. For the ATPLs, as per the learning objective above, the examiner is talking about alternating current (AC), which has a varying voltage and current across it, going from maximum in one direction, to maximum in the other direction, many times per second. This looks like a sine wave, and can be measured in "cycles", with one cycle being from peak to peak, or from trough to trough. Frequency is the measure of how many cycles occur per unit of time. The SI (French - Système International - International system of units) for frequency is Hertz (Hz), which is "cycles per second". (Because "cycles" is a number without a unit, the derivation of Hertz from base units is actually just "per second", or s-1).

content.question: When flying in heavy precipitation, a pilot experiences communication issues. There is an increase in background noise and the pilot struggles to hear ATC. The pilot has previously flown this route multiple times and, when the weather has been clear, this has never happened. Other aircrafts seem to hear ATC fine. What is the most likely reason for the interference?

options.A: The aircraft has lost its earth point in its electrical system.
options.B: The batteries in your headset needs to be replaced.
options.C: The aircraft have lost multiple static wicks.
options.D: You are out of range from the ATC station.

key_points: STATIC WICKS Static wicks are long, thin extensions that are often attached to the outboard trailing edges of wings and horizontal and vertical stabilizers
Friction generated as an aircraft moves through the air can cause a buildup of static electricity
The wick transfers that electricity back into the atmosphere to prevent it from interfering with navigation and communication radios
learning.explanation: STATIC WICKS Static wicks are long, thin extensions that are often attached to the outboard trailing edges of wings and horizontal and vertical stabilizers. Friction generated as an aircraft moves through the air can cause a buildup of static electricity. The wick transfers that electricity back into the atmosphere to prevent it from interfering with navigation and communication radios. Static wicks dissipate precipitation static that can develop as you fly through areas of uncharged particles. These particles can exist as you fly through solid or liquid particles such as rain, snow, fog, dust or ash. As the airplane flies through the particles, positive charges deflect and negative charges attach to the airframe, building up and eventually discharging at certain points of the airframe where the static wicks are generally attached. Without the wicks, there is potential for audio disturbances, weak radio transmissions and even complete loss of communication.

content.question: The function of a constant speed drive is to ensure…

options.A: an equal AC voltage output from all generators.
options.B: that the generator produces a constant frequency.
options.C: that the output voltage remains constant irrespective of generator RPM.
options.D: that the starter-motor maintains a constant RPM irrespective of engine acceleration/deceleration.

key_points: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU, or CSD
The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred to as speed
In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current
learning.explanation: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU, or CSD. The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred to as speed. In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current. The output of the hydraulic motor, and therefore the speed of the motor is dictated by the angle of the swashplate. The angle of the swash plate will either limit or increase the oil flow towards the hydraulic and in turn affect the rpm of the engine. The angle of the swash plate is controlled by the speed governor, which in turn is controlled by the load controller. The load controller senses the output frequency of the alternator and will adjust the swash plate accordingly to increase or decrease the torque output to the generator. The CSD can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft at any time during the flight. However, only the engineers can reconnect the CSD, on the ground, with the engines off.

content.question: In a multi-cell lithium battery, one cell sets on fire. Which of the following is likely to happen?

options.A: The fire will spread to other cells within the battery.
options.B: The casing around the battery will prevent the fire damaging the other cells.
options.C: The pilot will be able to stop the fire manually.
options.D: The fire will be contained within the battery by the casing, so no danger exists.

key_points: One of the biggest threats to Ni-Cd (Nickel Cadmium) and Lithium Ion Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway

The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating
Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly
learning.explanation: One of the biggest threats to Ni-Cd (Nickel Cadmium) and Lithium Ion Batteries is the risk of thermal runaway. The basic idea of thermal runaway is that if the battery becomes too hot (usually during charging), its internal resistance will change, causing it to produce more heat, hence heating it up further, causing a positive feedback loop that ends in extreme overheating. Lithium Ion batteries are even more prone to it than the old Ni-Cd batteries, and it can happen much more quickly. It often happens due to overcharging/overheating and a combination of the two. Damage is also a massive factor in the thermal runaway of lithium ion batteries, as these have very high energy densities, so can suffer from very high currents if two different parts of the battery meet unexpectedly. The worst case scenario in a thermal runaway is that a fire begins. Fire is pretty much the worst case scenario onboard any aircraft, other than complete structural failure perhaps, and lithium ion battery fires burn extremely hot. Almost all lithium ion batteries are made up of separate cells packed next to each other, with a battery controller linking the cells together and providing balanced charging, discharge, etc. Any fire from one cell (which burns incredibly hot as we have mentioned) will almost certainly spread to the other cells, and there is no way that most battery cases are able to contain that fire, as they burn in the region of thousands of degrees.

content.question: In aircraft with AC generators as primary source of electrical power DC power is obtained by…

options.A: AC-DC regulators
options.B: portable batteries

key_points: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier
Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another
These units are used in situations where AC distribution system needs to supply a DC system
learning.explanation: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another. These units are used in situations where AC distribution system needs to supply a DC system. The other answers are incorrect: “Rectifiers and voltage reducing resistors” – Even though rectifiers are commonly used to convert AC to DC, using resistors to lower the voltage have many disadvantages. Firstly, resistors dissipate power as heat, therefore the system will lose energy to lower the voltage, this is something that transformers typically do not. Secondly, the voltage drop of a resistor is dependent on the load, therefore cause fluctuations in voltage. This is something that doesn’t typically happen with transformers. “AC-DC Regulators” – Regulators work very similarly to resistors, hence they lose energy by turning it into heat. Therefore they are much less efficient than transformers. “Portable batteries” – Even though portable batteries would be able to power the DC power, and it is required that batteries can power the main system in case of an emergency, they would not be able to power the aircraft for the entire flight. Therefore DC batteries would never entirely power the DC system unless in an emergency.

content.question: A DC electric motor slows down due to an increased load. The armature current will (1) _____ and the torque will (2) _____.

options.A: (1) decrease, (2) increase.
options.B: (1) increase, (2) increase.

key_points: Inside a DC electrical motor, when a load is added, the rotor (spinning section) of the motor will slow down, due to the extra mechanical resistance to its spin
If this occurs, then all of a sudden, the motor is not cutting as many lines of flux (moving as quickly through the magnetic field), which means that the "back EMF" is reduced
This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical current due to the energy being turned into kinetic energy
learning.explanation: Inside a DC electrical motor, when a load is added, the rotor (spinning section) of the motor will slow down, due to the extra mechanical resistance to its spin. If this occurs, then all of a sudden, the motor is not cutting as many lines of flux (moving as quickly through the magnetic field), which means that the "back EMF" is reduced. This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical current due to the energy being turned into kinetic energy. (Lenz's Law) The back EMF acts against the armature coil, which is the set of spinning coils in the centre of the motor. If this back EMF (resistive force) is reduced, that means that for the same voltage, the current can flow more easily, so the current will increase. With an increased current, the available force from the motor per turn will also increase, and this is known as the torque. Therefore, to summarise, increasing the load on a DC motor decreases the spin speed, which decreases the electrical resistance (back EMF), thereby increasing the current, which increases the torque.

content.question: What is "load shedding"?

options.A: The process of increasing electrical load to ensure system stability.
options.B: The process of reducing electrical load during high-demand situations.
options.C: The process of redistributing fuel load for optimal balance.
options.D: The process of starting an extra generator to balance the load.

key_points: Load Shedding is the process of removing and reducing electrical loads on a system to ensure the system can continue running correctly
This could be for a few different reasons: If the system is degraded to a single generator, perhaps which is unable to run the full system load
The system will become unstable and will start failing when sufficient power can not be provided by the generator(s)
learning.explanation: Load Shedding is the process of removing and reducing electrical loads on a system to ensure the system can continue running correctly. This could be for a few different reasons: If the system is degraded to a single generator, perhaps which is unable to run the full system load. The system will become unstable and will start failing when sufficient power can not be provided by the generator(s). If the system is degraded down to battery power only, where load shedding is essential to save battery power to get you on the ground safely. If the system is under very high load, and the operating power sources may not be enough to power everything. This likely means a bad system design, but this is what we think the correct answer is talking about. Therefore, non-essential loads are shed to reduce overall system load or save battery. This may be automatic or manual, and some aircraft have a "shed bus" or multiple of them, which automatically stop being powered when a generator fails, or the load becomes too high, etc. Manual load shedding can be done by removing systems such as IFE (in-flight entertainment) or galley power, which are the first systems to go.

This flash of electricity reaches temperatures of 20 000°C
Arcing can and will cause a fire

Frequent and/or incoherent tripping of circuit breakers (CBs) as well as radio communication interference may occur if cables are poorly insulated, but this is not the most significant risk.

content.question: An AC generator provides a constant output voltage, when the electrical load increases. What will the voltage regulator do?

options.A: Increase the excitation current.
options.B: Decrease the excitation current.
options.C: Change the direction of the excitation current.
options.D: Nothing, the voltage will not need to change.

key_points: An aircraft AC generator is connected to the auxiliary gearbox of an engine (usually a turbine engine for these questions) via a constant speed drive
It works in the opposite sense to a motor, and turns the rotation into electrical energy
It requires the field coils to produce a magnetic field, which is then spinning (due to the rotation) and inducing a voltage on the fixed armature coils around the edge of the motor
learning.explanation: An aircraft AC generator is connected to the auxiliary gearbox of an engine (usually a turbine engine for these questions) via a constant speed drive. It works in the opposite sense to a motor, and turns the rotation into electrical energy. It requires the field coils to produce a magnetic field, which is then spinning (due to the rotation) and inducing a voltage on the fixed armature coils around the edge of the motor. The frequency of the AC output is governed by the constant speed drive, and the voltage is governed by the voltage regulator. The voltage (usually 115 V AC) is constantly produced by the generator, due to the voltage regulator modifying the amount of current that flows through the field coils. This voltage will change based on the electrical load applied within that circuit. If the electrical load increases, the current flow will increase, which will cause a drop in the voltage over the armature coils. You can think of this as the generator not being able to provide free extra power without making any changes. learning.explanation: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit. They prevent the maximum power rating of a component or wire from being exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating. Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit. There’re 3 types of fuses commonly used in electrical circuits: Cartridge fuse – tubular glass or ceramic body, 2 brass end caps and a tinned copper wire (or silver wire, or pure zinc). High rupture capacity (HRC) – designed for high current rated equipment. Current limiter fuse – high melting point fuses allowing them to carry a significant overload current before rupturing. All fuses have a current-specific rating (in amperes) that will indicate the maximum current they will be able to carry continuously or intermittently without excessively heating and rupturing. The rating of a fuse is designed so that it is not less than the current normally flowing in the circuit, but it ruptures just slightly below the safety limit of the equipment used. A fuse simply consists of a type of wire, as described above, that has a low melting point. learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.08.02: Describe the following five basic logic functions, as used in aircraft FCOM documentation, and recognise their schematic symbols according to the ANSI/MIL standard: AND; OR; NOT; NOR; NAND. Logic gates are the building blocks of computer processing. Computers operate at the deepest level in binary, a series of transistors holding either a value of 1 or 0. Logic gates allow these 1s and 0s to be calculated, and these very simple functions can be combined and programmed at a much higher level that can then become computer programs. For our simple purposes, an integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output will result. The five basic logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted "AND" output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted "OR" output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

key_points: As airplanes fly through the air, the friction of the air particles against the skin of the aircraft creates static electricity

learning.explanation: As airplanes fly through the air, the friction of the air particles against the skin of the aircraft creates static electricity. The static may build up unequally between aircraft parts and this could lead to sparks between the components. These sparks could lead to a fire. Therefore aircraft bonding between parts is installed to prevent the potential difference from being created between the parts, and therefore preventing any sparks from occurring. Bonding in itself is simply to connect all components of the aircraft with flexible wire strips, creating an easy path for electrons to pass between parts. On top of assuring a equal potential difference, the bonding system can also be used as a earth return system for a unipole circuit. Incorrect answers: “eliminate the need for grounding the aircraft during refuelling.” – The wires create a connection between the aircraft parts, but not to the ground. “prevent the aircraft being struck by lightning.” – Even though the grounding system will help the electrons from the lighting pass through the aircraft, it will not prevent the aircraft from being hit by a lightning strike. “ensure the electrical potential of the aircraft structure remains at 0 volts.” – The bonding system ensures that the potential difference between the components is zero, not that the entire aircraft structure remains at 0 volts.

For example, a 5Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2.5 Amperes in 2 hours, or even 10 amperes in 30 minutes. That is, the current (A) multiplied by time (Hr) in hours equals ampere hours. A. 10 Amperes x 10 hours = 100 Ah (correct) B. 5 Amperes x 10 hours = 50 Ah (wrong) C. 10 Amperes x 0.25 hours (15 minutes) = 2.5 Ah (wrong) D. 5 Amperes x 0.5 hours (30 minutes) = 2.5 Ah (wrong) If two identical batteries are connected in parallel the output voltage will remain the same and the capacity expressed in ampere-hours will double. content.question: Regarding the load factor, an aircraft's maximum allowable load factor is determined by the manufacturer. For a particular aircraft, the maximum load limit with flaps extended is half of the load factor in the clean configuration. Which of the following options completes the statement correctly? In level and unaccelerated flight...

options.A: the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended.
options.B: the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration.
options.C: the margin between actual load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle.
options.D: the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended.

key_points: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight
the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended
" This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended
learning.explanation: Let's go through each answer: "In level and unaccelerated flight. the difference between maximum load limit for flaps extended and clean wing is necessary as structural strength of the wing is lower with flaps extended." This is saying that the wing is weaker when flaps are extended. This is not correct, as the wing structure does not rely of the flaps. What actually causes the lower maximum load factor with flaps extended is the flap mechanism. With flaps extended, the higher the load factor, the more force is travelling through the mechanism which locks the flaps down, which are moving parts, so not as strong as the wing itself. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor with flaps extended will be higher than the load factor in the clean configuration." The load factor is simply lift/weight, and in straight and level flight, the lift will always equal the weight, therefore the load factor is 1, whether the flaps are up and down. It has not specified straight flight, but the same would be true in a turn of a particular bank angle; load factor is the same, with or without flaps. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the margin between current load factor and maximum load factor decreases with increased bank angle." Correct. In a level turn, the aircraft's wings have to produce a higher lift force, as the lift force is no longer straight upwards, but is instead pointing into the direction of turn somewhat. The steeper the bank angle, the greater the lift force has to be (to remain level), which means that the actual load factor has to increase. As the maximum load factor is a fixed value, the margin between actual and maximum decreases with increased bank angle. "In level and unaccelerated flight. the load factor at which structural damage occurs can never be more than +2.0G when flaps are extended." We had no feedback for this option, so made this up to fill in the gap. It is incorrect because flaps can be made as strong as you like. They could manage up to +15G if the manufacturer wants to. There are minimum values to their strength though, defined in the certification specifications.

learning.explanation: An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times. When an aircraft manoeuvres, for instance by entering a turn, the load factor on the wings increases, as the wings are now required to produce more lift than before. This leads to a change in the stress (and therefore strain) on the aircraft, in particular for this scenario, an increased load on the wing spars and roots, which cause a flex in the wing, demonstrating the extra strain present. Therefore, for this question, any force increase will increase the stress on the aircraft (as stress is force per unit area) and any stress will increase strain (the aircraft's deformation due to the stress).

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.01: Explain how stress and strain are always present in an aircraft structure both when parked and during manoeuvring. Remark: Stress is the internal force per unit area inside a structural part as a result of external loads. Strain is the deformation caused by the action of stress on a material. An aircraft is constantly subject to various forces; tension, compression, torsion and shearing forces are all occurring in an aircraft in varying amounts. For instance, when stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. Also, The weight of the whole aircraft is being opposed by reaction forces that travel through the landing gear and all the structurally load bearing components of the structure. These are amongst the many forces acting on a stationary aeroplane. The forces are very different when flying in straight and level (1 G) flight, where, for instance, the wings are suspending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. The rest of the aircraft also sustains new forces, such as that of pressurisation on the pressure hull. The forces change again during manoeuvres, taxi, take-off and landing. Any of these forces can be described in terms of stress and strain. Stress is the measure of force applied (per unit of cross-sectional area) whereas strain is the measure of deformation, usually as a proportion of the original size of the component. They are present on almost every item in some way, and are present in a multitude of different ways on an aircraft at all times.

learning.explanation: The rate of corrosion is the speed at which any given metal deteriorates in a specific environment. The performance of atmospherically exposed metals depends on five main factors: temperature, humidity, rainfall, sulphur dioxide (pollution) concentration in the air, and air salinity. Temperature - an increase in temperature will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. A rule of thumb is that temperature increases of 10°C will double the corrosion rate. Humidity - has a direct effect on the rate of corrosion of metals. The higher the humidity, the higher the rate of corrosion. Rainfall - leads to an increased humidity - therefore, higher rate of corrosion. Sulphur Dioxide (pollution) - is known to cause considerable damage to materials. These pollutants can accelerate the rate of corrosion. Air Salinity - an increase in air salinity levels will generally cause an increase in the corrosion rate. The salt from the oceans is a large factor in this. Flying close to warm oceanic surfaces (low level over the tropical seas) is probably the worst possible environment for corrosion, due to the warm, humid, salty air.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.02: Describe the following types of loads that an aircraft may be subjected to, when they occur, and how a pilot may affect their magnitude: static loads; dynamic loads; cyclic loads. As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are three types of load, but they are not completely mutually exclusive. Static loads are loads that do not change in size, position or direction. These could be loads such as the weight of the aircraft through the wheels when parked, or the tension on the upper skin of the wing when on the ground. They are quite easy to account for. Dynamic loads are loads that do change in size, position or direction. They must be accounted for more heavily by engineers, as a constantly changing load can cause more fatigue or early failure if not expected. There are countless dynamic loads on an aircraft, taxiing loads, the engine pylons, the bending of the wing spar in turbulent flight, the control surfaces during manoeuvring, etc. Cyclic loads are a special type of the aforementioned loads. They are loads which have expected cycles, the main one being the pressurisation cycle of the aircraft. It is a static load when non-pressurised and when fully pressurised, but dynamic as it changes. The cyclical nature does mean that engineers can build it to last, and monitor it's progress also, giving an aircraft a number of available pressurisation cycles, which can dictate its lifespan. This question simply wants you to know that there are constantly loads of all types occuring on an aircraft at all times. static loads also occur whilst in flight, and dynamic loads occur on the ground, even when parked (wind, boarding, etc.), so the two statements are both incorrect.

We would consider this scenario to be "on-condition maintenance", but the examiner may well disagree with that. See the individual explanations of each option below. We can look at each option individually: "The aircraft can be considered airworthy provided a visual inspection of the aircraft does NOT reveal technical malfunctions. This is referred to as condition monitoring." Reported as incorrect. What this option describes is effectively a pre-flight check, as the person undertaking the inspection is not identified, and the pilot must do this before every flight anyway, and therefore does not include the fact that the aircraft has been parked for a while. "The airworthiness maintenance statement could also contain a due date for hard-time maintenance after a certain number of cycles." This option is phrased very badly, but at the moment it is our best guess at the correct answer. It is all quite true, and some items are not expected to wear whilst the aircraft is parked, etc., but the words "due date" are misleading as how can it be known when an aircraft will complete that many cycles in the future? "After each parking period, irrespective of the duration, the airworthiness maintenance statement will need to be revised. This is an example of a hard-time maintenance method." We would, however, argue that this is not an example of hard time maintenance, which is the flaw in this option. content.question: What is the purpose of redundancy in aircraft design?

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.01.01.02: Explain the purpose of redundancy in aircraft design. Redundancy is another word for additional, or duplicate, and means that there is not just one load path or one source for any system. Essentially, to provide the correct amount of safety in the case of a failure under the "fail-safe" design concept, there needs to be another option to stop a catastrophic event occurring. For structural items, this is usually multiple load paths, so that if one breaks, the other can take the required forces without fully breaking. For systems, there are usually extra sources (electrical power, hydraulic pressure, etc.) to stop a complete failure of the more essential systems, such as flight controls or landing gear extension.

learning.explanation: Note: This should be a principles of flight question really, as per the learning objectives, but it has been reported mutiple times in AGK. The limit load (usually known as limit load factor) of an aeroplane is the maximum load it is expected to experience during flight operations. The aircraft must be capable of withstanding 150% of this "limit load" before failure occurs (which is the "ultimate load"). CS-25 aircraft, for instance, have a limit load factor of 2.5G at the minimum, meaning that they must be tested to 3.75G (150% of 2.5) without failure. Any forces higher than 2.5G can begin to cause irreversible bending of the airframe and are not assured to be withstood by every airframe in a fleet, so it is never recommended to exceed this limit load factor unless extreme circumstances make it necessary for safety.

learning.explanation: Corrosion is where two substances begin to change the composition of each other when mixed. Sometimes this is by literally breaking down the composition of the other substance, which is the most dramatic form of corrosion. This happens when one of the substances is corrosive to the other one. For instance, Mercury is HIGHLY corrosive to aluminium, and burns straight through aluminium if the two come into contact (also producing toxic fumes; they really are not a very pleasant combination). To address the options in this question: Mercury is corrosive (to aluminium and a few other metals particularly) as stated earlier. Battery Acid is corrosive also. Hydraulic Fluid is annoyingly complex when it comes to corrosiveness. One of the favourable properties of a good hydraulic fluid is for it to be non-corrosive. This is the case when it is in contact with metal, but it can be corrosive to paintwork, certain types of rubber seals, etc. Water is corrosive due to oxidisation, which causes rust. It is not highly corrosive, but the air contained within water will slowly break down materials like unprotected metals. Toilet Waste is a mixture of water (corrosive) and ammonia, as well as bacteria, all of which are corrosive to various materials

learning.explanation: Structural design concepts are developed to ensure safe operation of aircraft components. The Safe-life philosophy indicates that a component in the aircraft has a given time period or life cycle that it should withstand without any failure. The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time. This principle is called redundancy.

content.question: Windshield heating of a transport aeroplane is…

options.A: used to clear rain.
options.B: only used when hot-air demisting is insufficient.
options.C: essential to improve the strength and flexibility of the cockpit windows.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance.

key_points: MATERIALS Modern aircraft are constructed mainly of aluminium and its alloys with smaller amounts of steel and titanium for the major structural components with composite materials used extensively for more lightly loaded structures
However many of the latest aircraft make use of modern composites for the empennage, cabin floor panels, flying control surfaces, engine cowlings and fairings
Each material is chosen for its particular properties with regard to fatigue strength, wear resistance, strength to weight ratio, fire resistance etc
learning.explanation: MATERIALS Modern aircraft are constructed mainly of aluminium and its alloys with smaller amounts of steel and titanium for the major structural components with composite materials used extensively for more lightly loaded structures. However many of the latest aircraft make use of modern composites for the empennage, cabin floor panels, flying control surfaces, engine cowlings and fairings. Each material is chosen for its particular properties with regard to fatigue strength, wear resistance, strength to weight ratio, fire resistance etc. COMPOSITE MATERIALS Composite materials are made of at least two elements to produce a material with properties that are different to those of the original elements. Nearly all composites consist of a bulk material, this is called the matrix and some form of reinforcement. This reinforcement is used mainly to increase the strength and stiffness of the matrix and is usually in a fibre form. ADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - The ability to arrange the fibres to obtain directional properties consistent with the load - The ability to make complex shapes, since the material is not homogeneous - Weight savings - Resistance to corrosion - High specific strength - High specific stiffness DISADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - They are quickly eroded by hail, sand, etc, so leading edges must be sheathed. - They are difficult to repair. - They can absorb moisture if the material is not correctly sealed. When comparing composite and metal structures, composite are: - Lighter: Composites can be up to 70 percent lighter than metal. - High strength-to-weight ratio: composites have a high strength-to-weight ratio. Carbon fiber weighs about 25% as much as steel and 70% as much as aluminum, and is much stronger and stiffer than both materials per weight. Therefore, statement II is incorrect. - Stronger: When increasing the strength of metal, it must be equally strong in all directions thickening the material and causing an increase in weight. Composites however can be engineered and designed to be strong in a specific direction while keeping it lightweight. Therefore, statement I is incorrect. - Corrosion Resistant: Composites resist weather damage and other harsh chemicals that would typically damage metal. - Nonconductive: Unlike steel, composites are nonconductive.

The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. learning.explanation: Flight deck windows installed in pressurized aircraft must endure the stresses of pressurization as well as potential impacts from bird strikes. To secure the windows, they are fastened to the frame using bolts that pass through the edges of the windscreen. content.question: Which of the following statements correctly details the reasons and implications for some aircraft designs mounting the horizontal stabiliser on top of the fin (T-tail)?

options.A: It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.B: It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack.
options.C: It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.D: It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin.

key_points: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable. Learning Objective 021.02.03.01.01: Describe the following types of design and explain their advantages and disadvantages: high-mounted wing; low-mounted wing; low- or mid-set tailplane; T-tail. There are two main places that an aircraft designer can mount a horizontal stabiliser at the rear of an aircraft. One place is "low mounted", at the base of the tail fin, and the other place is at the top of the fin, a "T-tail" due to its shape looking like the letter "T". The low-mounted position tends to be more common on large civilian transport aircraft these days, but both mounting locations have their own positive and negative factors. We will now talk about T-tail in comparison to low-mounted. T-tails have the horizontal stabiliser up and away from the turbulence created by the wing (during normal flight), which means the airflow over the tailplane is smoother. As the tailplane is therefore less affected by the downwash from the main wing, we can refer to this mounting position as "stabilising" (some questions in PoF ask about this). T-tails also make the fin and rudder more effective, as they act as a winglet for the fin and rudder, so a smaller rudder is required. However, all the forces produced by the horizontal stabiliser and the elevators must travel through the fin, meaning that the fin must be made much stronger (and therefore heavier) than if the stabiliser was mounted on the fuselage at the bottom. Also, a more practical consideration is that inspection is more difficult, especially when it comes to icing/de-icing. The final consideration for a T-tail is probably the most well known. The horizontal stabiliser may be out of the way of the turbulence from the wing during normal flight, but at high angles of attack, the tailplane will now be within the stalled region behind the wing, leading to a stall where no elevator control is possible, called a deep-stall. Deep-stalls can sometimes be unrecoverable. So let's go through the options. "It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. It has a stabilising effect on the aircraft, so decreases manoeuvrability. It is not simpler to design, requiring a very strong fin. It is obviously harder to inspect though, that bit is correct. "It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack." Correct, as mentioned above, the smoother airflow is correct, the stronger, heavier fin is also correct, and the last section which refers to a deep-stall at high angles of attack is correct as well for a T-tail. "It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. Ground clearance is debatable, as an aircraft's wings are usually more of a concern for that. It is not simpler to design, as it requires a stronger fin. The last section about de-icing is correct, though. "It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin." Incorrect. Smoother airflow, yes; but it certainly does not have a wider operating range in pitch, as it suffers from deep-stalls, becoming useless at high angles of attack. It does require a heavier fin though.
