key_points: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators
Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure
An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards
learning.explanation: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators. Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure. An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards. If the aircraft is subjected to a gust it will shake up and down with the wings flapping at a certain frequency. If the vibration is similar to that of the structure of the wing then it will begin to resonate. The resonance will amplify the flutter and may well lead to failure of the structure. Flutter must not occur within the normal flight operating envelope of the aircraft. Flutter can be prevented by mass balancing control surfaces to alter the moment of inertia of the surface and therefore the period of vibration (move the control surface C of G from behind the hinge to closer to the hinge). Poorly maintained aircraft, particularly those with excessive control surface backlash (play) or flexibility may mean that flutter could occur at speeds below the limit airspeed.

key_points: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be strong

learning.explanation: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be strong. To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers. A heating element is added to the tough outer glass. There are two main benefits of heating: The first is icing resistance due to the increased temperature of the surface. Windshield heat controllers are generally capable of handling two primary functions: de-fog and de-ice. Cockpit side windows often do not feature window heating but are only equipped with defogging devices. The second is that the heated glass stays in a temperature range where it is less rigid. Window heating ensures the screen vinyl layer is kept elastic and resilient and better to absorb damage in case of a bird strike/hail. For this reason most, if not all, commercial aircraft with heated windshields will have a speed restriction below 10 000 ft if the windshield heat is inoperative, commonly not above 250 KIAS below 10 000 ft.

content.question: When is a wing not subject to any tension or compression forces?

options.A: when stationary in the hangar.
options.B: when the aircraft is still brand new at the factory.
options.C: when the aircraft is flying at 1 g.
options.D: never, the wings are always subject to various forces.

key_points: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases
When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root
This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed
learning.explanation: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases. When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. This effect is increased with any increased weight of the wing, engines fitted or fuel inside the wings. The effect is reversed when flying in straight and level (1g) flight, where the wings are supending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. This effect is increased when the lift increases (larger all-up weight, higher load factor, etc.) and also when the fuel in the wings is less, and there would be less weight resistance to the upwards flexing effect. The wing flex of different scenarios can be seen in the annex depicting a B52.

content.question:
Which of the following can a pilot do to reduce the risk of overloading the airframe?
1. Avoid headwinds
2. Avoid large bank angles
3. Avoid turbulence
4. Fly below VA
5. Avoid tailwinds

key_points: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft
It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings
Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots
learning.explanation: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft. It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings. Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots. Hence, they are usually the strongest place on the entire aircraft. A very high stress scenario for the aircraft is pulling any sort of G-force, which requires increasing the load factor of the wings, and that means the lift of the wing has to increase. Large transport aircraft (CS-25) have a "limit load factor" of 2.5 G, and must be able to pull 150% of this (3.75 G) before complete structural failure occurs. This means that an aircraft will have to show during testing that the structure (mostly the wing spar and wing root) can withstand a lifting force of 3.75 times its own maximum take-off weight, which can be an incredible amount of force, before failing. Any G-force over the limit load factor is an "overload". An aircraft increases its loading during manoeuvres, so in banked turns (the greater the bank, the higher the wing loading), and any abrupt changes in direction, pitch, etc. Also, the loading increases in turbulence and any windshear. Aircraft stress obviously increases with weight, but the limiting load factor is set for the MTOW, so it can only get better as the aircraft gets lighter. VA is the manoeuvring speed, and if flying below VA, the aircraft will be unable to pull its limit load factor during a manoeuvre, as it will stall first, and therefore will not overload the airframe. Headwinds and tailwinds do not affect loading, as the aircraft just flies through the air mass it is in, and the head/tailwinds simply move the air mass forwards or backwards, increasing or decreasing groundspeed. As long as the winds do not change rapidly (windshear), this should not affect aircraft loading.

learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.13: Explain the function of floor venting (blow-out panels). Floor vents (blow-out panels) exist in an aircraft to provide a location for easy flow of air in the event of a depressurisation between the cargo hold and the passenger cabin. If a rapid depressurisation event occurred from a hole in the cargo hold, then the high pressure in the passenger cabin would push down very strongly on the floor, causing it to buckle. The floor vents are panels in and around the floor that easily break/open, leaving a gap where the air can equalise pressure without further damage.

content.question: Which of the following actions can be taken to reduce the chance of a tail strike during take-off?

options.A: Reduce rotation rate.
options.B: Accurately calculate take-off performance data.
options.D: Maintain a steep take-off angle after rotation.

key_points: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off
Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment
If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground
learning.explanation: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off. Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment. If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground. Conversely, if the rotation speed is too low, the aircraft may not achieve the desired pitch attitude for liftoff, potentially causing a tail strike as well. The two major threats for tail strikes to occur are during the landing flare/touchdown and during rotation on take-off. As many large jet transport aircraft are extended in length for larger passenger numbers, the long tail leaves very little tail margin during rotation, and factors such as crosswinds, gusty head/tailwinds and different weight and CG locations can lead to the potential for reduced tail clearance or tail strike. To mitigate this risk, pilots can choose to rotate at a slightly higher speed, if, for instance, they feel a gust just before rotation that might reduce their airspeed significantly. A higher airspeed means more airflow over the wings and therefore the aircraft will lift-off at a lower pitch angle, and the tail will therefore be further clear of the ground before reaching the tail strike angle. The pilot could also reduce the rate of rotation to further reduce the chance of tail strikes occurring (as might be done in an engine failure after V1 scenario), but this is not usually recommended in normal operation, and remember that both of these measures are not accounted for in the take-off performance calculation, so be careful not to run out of runway.

content.question:
Wing fluttering can be caused by which of the following types of deformation?
1. Elongation
2. Bending
3. Shearing
4. Torsion

options.A: 1 and 2
options.B: 3 and 4

key_points: Wing flutter is a dynamic instability of an aircraft associated with the interaction of aerodynamic (bending and torsion), elastic, and inertial forces
Wing flutter is most commonly caused by either the wing bending moment (up and down about the wing root), or the torsion (twisting) of the wing about the main spar
These deformations are lagged by the movement of control surfaces, which can lead to quite large oscillations, with heavy vibrations, and ultimately aircraft structural failure
learning.explanation: Wing flutter is a dynamic instability of an aircraft associated with the interaction of aerodynamic (bending and torsion), elastic, and inertial forces. Wing flutter is most commonly caused by either the wing bending moment (up and down about the wing root), or the torsion (twisting) of the wing about the main spar. These deformations are lagged by the movement of control surfaces, which can lead to quite large oscillations, with heavy vibrations, and ultimately aircraft structural failure.

content.question: Which material has a high strength to weight ratio, but is the most susceptible to corrosion?

options.A: Composite
options.B: Wood

key_points: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft
Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc
The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry)
learning.explanation: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft. Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc. The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry). Different metals have different levels of strength, they are different to work with, and are used in different sections of the aircraft. For instance, the fuselage is usually made from an easily manufactured aluminium alloy, but sections of the hot engine are made from the very expensive, but incredibly heat resistant titanium. Alloys are a clever way of combining the different properties of two or more metals to make them better for the required usage. Now to answer this question. In general, metal has a high strength to weight ratio (in that it is strong but also light). The only better type of material for strength to weight ratio is composites. Composites such as carbon fibre, aramid (Kevlar), fibreglass, and plastic composites can be made incredibly strong, but far lighter than metals. Their fibres can also be aligned to create strength in particular directions, which is much harder to do in metal. The answer is not composites though, because they are very resistant to corrosion. Metal, however, is highly susceptible to corrosion, and it is a large part of what engineers check for and treat when they maintain an aircraft.

content.question: How do windscreen heating systems usually work?

options.A: They cycle on and off to keep the screen temperature within a specific range.
options.B: They depend on the pilot monitoring the screen temperature probe for controlling the screen heat.
options.C: They are powered from the DC emergency (hot) bus.
options.D: They consist of warm air from cabin heat blown onto the windscreen.

key_points: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be very strong
To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers
Heating elements are added to the tough outer glass
learning.explanation: Since pressurisation forces are to be resisted by flight deck windows as well as the cabin structure, the windows need to be very strong. To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers. Heating elements are added to the tough outer glass. There are two main benefits of heating: The first is icing resistance due to the increased temperature of the surface. Windshield heat controllers are generally capable of handling two primary functions: de-fog and de-ice. Cockpit side windows often do not feature window heating but are only equipped with defogging devices. The second is that the heated glass stays in a temperature range where it is less rigid. The heating elements usually heat the windows into this temperature range, switch off so they do not overheat, then switch back on again if the window is going to cool down too much, cycling like this throughout every flight. Window heating ensures the screen vinyl layer is kept elastic and resilient and better to absorb damage in case of a bird strike/hail. For this reason most, if not all, commercial aircraft with heated windshields will have a speed restriction below 10 000 ft if the windshield heat is inoperative, commonly that restriction is to be not above 250 KIAS below 10 000 ft.

content.question: Wing flutter may be prevented by…

options.A: Locating mass in front of the torsion axis of the wing.
options.B: Increasing the aspect ratio of the wing.
options.C: Mounting the engines on the fuselage.
options.D: Installing the fuel tanks in the fuselage.

key_points: Flutter is a periodic aeroelastic process
It is a self-induced oscillation, at which different oscillations are coupled via aerodynamic and inertial forces

Energy for the oscillation is provided by the airstream with velocity (v), the "channel" through which the energy is transmitted is lift (changes in lift) and used by the flexible system (having mass and elasticity)
learning.explanation: Flutter is a periodic aeroelastic process. It is a self-induced oscillation, at which different oscillations are coupled via aerodynamic and inertial forces. Energy for the oscillation is provided by the airstream with velocity (v), the "channel" through which the energy is transmitted is lift (changes in lift) and used by the flexible system (having mass and elasticity). If the CG is in the hinge, wing bending - controls surface flutter will not be started. Therefore, CG of the control is moved towards the hinge by the means of mass and balance by adding an extra weight in front of the torsion axis of the wing.

content.question: One function of a rib is...

options.C: to connect the stringers to the wing skin.
options.D: to carry tensile load of the fuselage pressure hull.

key_points: The internal structures of most wings are made up of: Spars and stringers which run spanwise; and Ribs running chordwise (leading edge to trailing edge)
Spars: are the main structural member of a wing, supporting all distributed loads and concentrated weights (such as the fuselage, landing gear, and engines)
Skin: is attached to the wing structure and carries part of the loads imposed during flight
learning.explanation: The internal structures of most wings are made up of: Spars and stringers which run spanwise; and Ribs running chordwise (leading edge to trailing edge). Spars: are the main structural member of a wing, supporting all distributed loads and concentrated weights (such as the fuselage, landing gear, and engines). Skin: is attached to the wing structure and carries part of the loads imposed during flight. It also transfers the stresses to the wing ribs. Ribs: perform similar functions to those performed by fuselage frames. They maintain the shape of the wing section, assist in transferring loads to the wing spars, and reduce the column length of the stringers.

content.question: Which of these properties is desirable in the materials used for constructing an airframe.

options.A: High susceptibility to corrosion.
options.B: High compressive strength and very brittle.

key_points: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft
Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, weight, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc
The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry)
learning.explanation: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft. Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, weight, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc. The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry). Strength-to-weight ratio is an important factor, as materials with a high strength-to-weight ratio are either stronger or lighter than other materials, both of which are useful for aviation. This is why metal and composites are so commonly used for aircraft construction, due to their high strength-to-weight ratios. As for the other options, susceptibility to corrosion is bad as it will weaken the airframe and potentially lead to failure. We want the material to be strong, but being brittle is not good, as it will be likely to snap or shatter instead of bending.

content.question: How may rivets be lost from an aircraft?

options.A: Due to engine failure or malfuntion.
options.B: Through corrosion over time.
options.C: Through improper maintenance or installation of the rivets.
options.D: Through hard landings or high manoeuvring loads.

key_points: Rivets are a commonly used method of attaching two materials together, often used to attach the skin of an airframe together

There are often thousands of rivets on an aircraft, and whilst they are not know for coming off, improper maintenance or worse, improper installation would certainly make them insecure, and likely to be lost during normal operations
Corrosion is unlikely to remove rivets on its own, as they are fused to the skin, and corrosion would have to be incredibly severe (and therefore noticeable) to start removing them completely
learning.explanation: Rivets are a commonly used method of attaching two materials together, often used to attach the skin of an airframe together. There are often thousands of rivets on an aircraft, and whilst they are not know for coming off, improper maintenance or worse, improper installation would certainly make them insecure, and likely to be lost during normal operations. Corrosion is unlikely to remove rivets on its own, as they are fused to the skin, and corrosion would have to be incredibly severe (and therefore noticeable) to start removing them completely. Hard landings and high manoeuvring loads can remove rivets, screws, and other fasteners through shearing forces, for example, if the "improper maintenance or installation" option is not present in the exam, this option should be chosen. With the options as they are, hard landing and manoeuvring loads are less likely to cause the complete loss of rivets than improper maintenance or installation. Engine failure or malfunction has nothing to do with the rivets really, and they should easily be able to deal with the forces involved.

content.question: Which of the following correctly describes the construction of flight deck windshields for commercial jet aircraft?

options.A: A single sheet of toughened glass, to give the pilots the best view outwards.
options.B: Flexible vinyl only, to withstand high differential pressures.
options.C: Two or three layers separated by air, to insulate the cockpit at high altitudes.
options.D: Layers of toughened glass and vinyl, to aid impact resistance from bird strike.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.09: Explain why flight-deck windows are constructed with different layers. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also sometimes contain layers of toughened (tempered) glass, as it is incredibly strong, and protects well against small impacts at high speed. The layering of different materials help to provide better impact resistance than one type of material only, combining the best features of all the materials. Aircraft windshields also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics (vinyl and acrylic) in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact.

content.question: An operator notices corrosion on some metal parts of their aircraft fleet. What actions should they take?

options.A: Wash the aeroplanes thoroughly after each flight.
options.B: Replace the metal parts affected by corrosion with plastic or composite materials where possible.
options.C: Repair, prime and paint the damaged parts.
options.D: Paint over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.02.01.02: State the advantages and disadvantages of composite materials compared with metal alloys by considering the following: strength-to-weight ratio; capability to tailor the strength to the direction of the load; stiffness; electrical conductivity (lightning); resistance to fatigue and corrosion; resistance to cost; discovering damage during a pre-flight inspection. The appropriate action to take if an operator notices corrosion on metal parts of their aircraft fleet is to repair, prime, and paint the damaged parts. This is important because corrosion can weaken the metal and compromise the structural integrity of the aircraft, which can be a safety hazard. Replacing the metal parts with plastic or composite materials may be an option, but it can be expensive and may not always be feasible. It is also important to note that different materials have different properties, and they may not be suitable for all applications. Washing the aircraft thoroughly after each flight may be important for general maintenance but may not prevent corrosion. A notable point is that washing the aircraft after every flight could cause some water based corrosion or rusting over time, so is not a good idea to fight corrosion. Painting over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength is not a recommended practice as it does not address the underlying corrosion issue and can lead to further damage. Therefore, the best course of action is to have the affected parts assessed by a qualified technician and have the corrosion removed and repaired, and then properly primed and painted to protect against further corrosion.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true about "plug type" aircraft doors?

options.A: They are always used in unpressurised aircraft.
options.B: Each door can move inside and outside the aircraft.
options.C: They must have a pressure relief valve.
options.D: They can only be hydraulically or electrically operated.

key_points: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside
There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors
Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation
learning.explanation: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside. There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors. Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation. This is why pressurised aircraft often use "plug type" doors, where the door is larger than the frame, and is mounted inside of the frame, so the door is being pushed into the door frame by the force of air pressure, acting like a "plug" for the hole. These doors have to be opened inwards into the aircraft, and then are usually hinged in such a way that they can go back through the door frame sideways and remain outside the aircraft whilst open. This is done primarily to reduce the space taken up inside the aircraft by the door, which also helps during an evacuation. Therefore, the most correct answer is that the door can move inside and outside the aircraft. As for the other options; They are not always used in unpressurised aircraft, in fact I imagine that is quite rare. They do not need a pressure relief valve, they are supposed to hold quite high pressure loads, and there will be an over-pressure relief valve somewhere on the aircraft fuselage. They can be manually operated, and often are.

content.question: The heating facility for the windshield of an aircraft is…

options.A: Used on a continual basis as it reduces the thermal gradients which adversely affect the useful life of the components.
options.B: Harmful to the integrity of the windows in the event of a bird strike.
options.C: Used only at low altitudes where there is a risk of ice formation.
options.D: Only used when hot air demisting is insufficient.

learning.explanation: 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds (it is therefore used on a continuous basis during the entire flight). If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance. Another rationale for the constant operation of the window heating system is the mitigation of thermal gradients. When the window heating system is activated, it ensures that the window pane remains at a consistent temperature throughout the entirety of the flight.

content.question: Which of the following sources of hydraulic pressure is commonly used for operation of cargo doors when the electric hydraulic pumps are not working?

options.A: Hydraulic accumulator.
options.B: Hand pump.

key_points: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics
They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system

However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics
learning.explanation: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics. They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system. However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics. As for the other options: Engine driven pumps require the engines to be on, and that would be very hazardous for ground crew trying to open the cargo doors, so is not feasible. A ram air turbine is a small wind turbine that drops from the underside of an aircraft to provide power/hydraulic pressure to important controls in flight. It is not used on the ground, nor would it be useful without any airflow through it. A hydraulic accumulator would likely still have some pressure in it during most ground operations, but it is not what you would use to operate the cargo doors, as it would quickly run out of pressure and is needed for the parking brakes in some aircraft, etc.

content.question: A hydraulic accumulator serves to…

options.A: Dampen fluctuations in hydraulic pressure, and act as a backup reservoir.
options.B: Dampen fluctuations in hydraulic pressure, and act as a primary reservoir.
options.C: Cool the hydraulic fluid, and act as a primary reservoir.
options.D: Cool the hydraulic fluid, and act as a backup reservoir.

key_points: An accumulator is fitted to store hydraulic fluid under pressure, dampen pressure fluctuations, allow for thermal expansion and provide an emergency supply of fluid to the system in the event of a pump failure
The gas side of the accumulator is charged to a predetermined pressure with air or nitrogen
As the accumulator is fitted and the hydraulic pressure in the system builds up, the gas in the accumulator will be compressed until fluid and gas pressures equalise at normal system pressure
learning.explanation: An accumulator is fitted to store hydraulic fluid under pressure, dampen pressure fluctuations, allow for thermal expansion and provide an emergency supply of fluid to the system in the event of a pump failure. The gas side of the accumulator is charged to a predetermined pressure with air or nitrogen. As the accumulator is fitted and the hydraulic pressure in the system builds up, the gas in the accumulator will be compressed until fluid and gas pressures equalise at normal system pressure. That is why the accumulator gauge will read the same as the hydraulic system is pressurised to.

content.question: You need to load some cargo into a large airplane that is currently shut down. How will you open the cargo compartment door?

options.A: Via a hand pump.
options.B: Use the control panel to open it electrically.
options.C: Use the control panel to open it hydraulically.
options.D: Attempt to open it manually by prying it open with a crowbar.

key_points: In small, light aircraft, hand pumps might be the sole source of power for the hydraulic system
In larger aircraft, however, they serve several important functions: Facilitating ground servicing without requiring the engines to run
Allowing for pressure testing of lines and joints
learning.explanation: In small, light aircraft, hand pumps might be the sole source of power for the hydraulic system. In larger aircraft, however, they serve several important functions: Facilitating ground servicing without requiring the engines to run. Allowing for pressure testing of lines and joints. Operating cargo doors and other components without external power. Hand pumps are typically double-acting, meaning they deliver oil on both the push and pull strokes, and are designed to be compact. They include non-return valves (NRVs) and a relief valve, which can be adjusted to relieve pressure at a specified level, generally about 10% higher than the normal system pressure.

content.question: Different types of hydraulic fluids can be mixed. This statement is…

options.A: True, but only vegetable and mineral hydraulic fluids can be mixed. Synthetic hydraulic fluids for high performance systems must not be mixed with any other type of fluid.

key_points: HYDRAULIC FLUIDS Hydraulic fluids make possible the transmission of pressure and energy
They also act as a lubricating medium, thereby reducing the friction between moving parts and carrying away some of the heat
Hydraulic fluids should be handled with care as they are considered to be a skin and eye irritant
learning.explanation: HYDRAULIC FLUIDS Hydraulic fluids make possible the transmission of pressure and energy. They also act as a lubricating medium, thereby reducing the friction between moving parts and carrying away some of the heat. Hydraulic fluids should be handled with care as they are considered to be a skin and eye irritant. In aviation, mainly mineral or synthetic based oil are used: DTD 585: a refined mineral based oil. Colour - red. Used with synthetic rubber seals. SKYDROL: a phosphate ester based oil (synthetic). Colour - purple or green, depending on type. Used with synthetic rubber seals. Is fire resistant and less prone to cavitation because of its higher boiling point. Due to the difference in composition, mineral-based and synthetic-based fluids will not mix; neither are the seals for any one fluid usable with or tolerant of any of the other fluids. Should an aircraft hydraulic system be serviced with the wrong type fluid, immediately drain and flush the system as breakdown of the seals is likely which will cause fluid leakage.

content.question: A hydraulic low pressure alert is the first indication of...

options.A: the pump output pressure being insufficient.
options.B: a leak in the reservoir return line.
options.C: the hydraulic system accumulator becoming deflated.
options.D: the reservoir level being at a minimum acceptable level.

key_points: Hydraulic systems are subjected to several significant threats, including: System Overheat
The system exceeds its maximum allowable operating temperature and must be de-energized
Pump overheat is normally caused by blockage of case drain cooling flow or blockage of heat exchanger
learning.explanation: Hydraulic systems are subjected to several significant threats, including: System Overheat. The system exceeds its maximum allowable operating temperature and must be de-energized. Pump overheat is normally caused by blockage of case drain cooling flow or blockage of heat exchanger. Low System Pressure. Low system pressure can occur due to loss of fluid, pressure filter blockage or failure of a hydraulic pump/insufficient pump output pressure. Pump low pressure may occur from a pump or drive shaft failure. Hydraulic Fluid Contamination. Contamination can be chemical or particulate, normally results from improper servicing of the hydraulic system or by a component failure. Hydraulic system overheat, Low system pressure or fluid contamination can all result in the loss of the hydraulic system and the loss of function of those components that it powers.

content.question:
Which of the following options are the purposes of an accumulator in a hydraulic system?
1) to damp pressure fluctuations
2) to cool the hydraulic fluid
3) to serve as a limited alternate source of pressure
4) to serve as a main pressure source for normal operation
5) to allow for thermal expansion

options.A: 1, 3 and 5
options.B: 2, 3 and 5

key_points: Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system
They are often used after a pump in a hydraulic system to do both these jobs, and by doing so increase efficiency and reduce the stresses on the hydraulic system

They can use a diaphragm (annex above) or a movable piston, with one side connected to the hydraulic lines and containing hydraulic fluid, but with the other side filled with gas (usually nitrogen), which can compress to the same pressure as the system
learning.explanation: Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system. They are often used after a pump in a hydraulic system to do both these jobs, and by doing so increase efficiency and reduce the stresses on the hydraulic system. They can use a diaphragm (annex above) or a movable piston, with one side connected to the hydraulic lines and containing hydraulic fluid, but with the other side filled with gas (usually nitrogen), which can compress to the same pressure as the system. They can also help with absorbing the pressure of thermal expansion within closed hydraulic systems, when the fluid expands or contract due to temperature changes, but cannot flow back to the resevoir. When the system is open, any excess fluid will flow into the reservoir. The are not used for aiding cooling.

content.question: The Ram Air Turbine (RAT) provides emergency hydraulic power for…

options.A: nose wheel steering after the aeroplane has landed.
options.B: undercarriage selection and automatic brake system.
options.D: flight controls in the event of loss of engine driven hydraulic power.

key_points: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies
In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment
The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump
learning.explanation: A Ram Air Turbine (RAT) is a small wind turbine that is installed in an aircraft to be used as a source of power during emergencies. In these cases, the RAT will power vital systems such as flight controls or flight-critical instrumentation, navigation and communication equipment. The RAT generates power from the airstream based on the speed of the aircraft and is connected to an electrical generator or to a hydraulic pump. Consequently, more power is generated when the aircraft is operating at a higher speed and less is generated when operating at lower speeds.

content.question: An aircraft is equipped with two individual hydraulic systems. One of the systems has a pump failure. How will the system alert the pilot?

options.A: A master caution and an amber light.
options.B: A master caution and a red light.
options.D: Either a red or amber light and an audio warning.

key_points: On large transport airplanes, sensors continuously monitor hydraulic systems, and the crew is informed of the system status and alerted in case of any malfunction
Low pressure or high temperatures may also indicate a failing pump that is underperforming and heating the fluid instead of increasing pressure due to an internal malfunction

A loss of hydraulic pressure in one system will trigger an amber master caution light, along with the associated “LOW PRESS” caution light of the affected system and removal of the system pressure reading on the hydraulic system page
learning.explanation: On large transport airplanes, sensors continuously monitor hydraulic systems, and the crew is informed of the system status and alerted in case of any malfunction. Low pressure or high temperatures may also indicate a failing pump that is underperforming and heating the fluid instead of increasing pressure due to an internal malfunction. A loss of hydraulic pressure in one system will trigger an amber master caution light, along with the associated “LOW PRESS” caution light of the affected system and removal of the system pressure reading on the hydraulic system page. Loss of one hydraulic system’s pump would trigger a caution as the aircraft can still operate with one hydraulic system. Caution message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action WILL be required. They are the next highest priority alert messages after warning messages, and they are usually amber.

content.question: Hydraulic fluids…

options.A: are highly flammable.
options.B: are irritating to eyes and skin.
options.D: can be used in the lubrication system.

key_points: HYDRAULIC FLUIDS Hydraulic fluids make possible the transmission of pressure and energy
They also act as a lubricating medium, thereby reducing the friction between moving parts and carrying away some of the heat
Hydraulic fluids should be handled with care as they are considered to be a skin and eye irritant
learning.explanation: HYDRAULIC FLUIDS Hydraulic fluids make possible the transmission of pressure and energy. They also act as a lubricating medium, thereby reducing the friction between moving parts and carrying away some of the heat. Hydraulic fluids should be handled with care as they are considered to be a skin and eye irritant. In aviation, mainly mineral or synthetic based oil are used: DTD 585: a refined mineral based oil. Colour - red. Used with synthetic rubber seals. SKYDROL: a phosphate ester based oil (synthetic). Colour - purple or green, depending on type. Used with synthetic rubber seals. Is fire resistant and less prone to cavitation because of its higher boiling point. Due to the difference in composition, petroleum-based and phosphate ester-based fluids will not mix; neither are the seals for any one fluid usable with or tolerant of any of the other fluids. Should an aircraft hydraulic system be serviced with the wrong type fluid, immediately drain and flush the system and maintain the seals according to the manufacturer’s specifications. Ideal properties of a hydraulic fluid: Low compressibility: to ensure instantaneous operation; Good lubrication and anti-corrision properties: hydraulic fluid acts as a lubricant for the pumps, actuators and motors within the system; High flash point and low flammability: fluid ignition should not occur at the normal operating temperatures of the surrounding components; Low volatility: be resistant to evaporation; Adequate viscosity: the fluid used must flow easily at very low temperatures but must also maintain adequate viscosity at high temperatures. The ideal hydraulic fluid will have a very low freezing point and a very high boiling point. Thermal stability.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The diagram shows a typical hydraulic system. Assuming hydraulic pressure throughout and no internal leakage, how will the piston move? The piston..

options.A: moves to the right due to equal pressure acting on differential areas.
options.B: moves to the left due to pressure acting on differential areas.

key_points: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you
Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus

A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses
learning.explanation: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you. Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus. A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses. It works by compressing nitrogen inside the accumulator with the force of the hydraulic fluid, and then the high pressure nitrogen is where the energy is stored. There are a few different ways to do this, via diaphragm, with a moving piston between the fluid and the nitrogen, and with no separation at all, just gravity. These are the types of gas charged accumulators, but there are also spring accumulators and even weighted accumulators that can be used. We do not normally look into these though. If an accumulator was mounted horizontally, the gravity option would not keep the fluid in the lines, so would not work. Therefore only a diaphragm or (more likely) a moving piston would be used in this orientation. This should mean that there is no cross-contamination of nitrogen and hydraulic fluid. The hydraulic fluid stays on one side of the piston/diaphragm, the nitrogen stays on the other side. If, as in this scenario, there is an amount of hydraulic fluid leaving the nitrogen release valve, then there must have been some sort of leak between the two, for hydraulic fluid to enter the nitrogen section.

In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure
learning.explanation: There are different ways of measuring and stating pressure. These include; Absolute pressure, which is referenced against a vacuum, Gauge pressure, which is referenced against ambient (usually atmospheric) pressure, and Differential pressure, which measures the difference between the pressures of two different locations. In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure. We can also work this out by thinking about what happens when you de-pressurise a hydraulic system completely. The hydraulic pressure will read 0 PSI, as the fluid is exerting the same amount of pressure on its surroundings as the atmosphere does. Atmospheric pressure is around 14.7 PSI greater than a vacuum (i.e. its absolute pressure is 14.7 PSI, or 1013 hPa). For instance, manifold pressure gauges read out MAP (Manifold Absolute Pressure), so show the absolute ambient pressure when the engine is off. Other systems rarely read out absolute pressure.

learning.explanation: A "swash plate pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump, also called a "demand pump". This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. Figure 1 shows the pump at maximum stroke and figure 2 shows the pump at minimum stroke, when the system is already at the correct pressure. learning.explanation: Brakes in a light aircraft operate in a similar way to many cars, in that the system is hydraulic. The pressure applied by the driver/pilot onto the brake pedal does work on the incompressible brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), which acts on a piston to push the brake pads into the brake discs, thereby applying the brakes. The harder the brake pedal is pushed, the more friction the brakes make. An active hydraulic system is used for braking (and many other things) on large aircraft, where a system is constantly pressurised and the brakes are operated by action on the brake pedals effectively turning a valve to allow more or less of that pressure to work on the brakes. This allows much stronger braking action than a human could possibly produce.

On its own it is not useful as it has varying pressure output, which could perhaps overpressure a system or burn out the pump motor, etc., so it has to be combined with an automatic cut-out valve (ACOV) which turns this constant voulme output into a constant pressure supply into a system. learning.explanation: ALTERNATE BRAKES Power brake actuating systems use the aircraft hydraulic system as the source of power to apply the brakes. Early aircraft had a single braking system with no backup or redundancy, meaning that any failure could result in total loss of braking capability. Nowadays, most large passenger aircraft have braking redundancy which is achieved by multiple, independent hydraulic systems backed up by accumulators. These systems allow for several layers of failure without resulting in total loss of braking capability. In most cases, the right hydraulic system supplies the normal brakes. If this is lost, there is an automatic switchover to Alternate Brakes powered by the center system. In addition to supply system redundancy, the brake accumulator is also an emergency source of power for the brakes in many power brake systems. content.question: A hydraulic demand pump in a large jet transport aeroplane adjusts its (1) _____ to meet system demand and usually operates in the range of (2) _____.

learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It runs at a constant RPM and modulates its volumetric flow output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. Figure 1 shows the pump at maximum stroke and figure 2 shows the pump at minimum stroke, when the system is already at the correct pressure. In terms of hydraulic pressures, most large transport aircraft have hydraulic pressures in the range of 3000 - 5000 psi as this is a good amount to power heavy control surfaces and landing gear systems, etc. Larger aircraft tend to have higher pressures in general, and the Airbus A380 runs hydraulic pressures of 5000 psi, whereas Boeing 737s run at 3000 psi.

learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. learning.explanation: Axial piston pumps are constant pressure pump (variable volume). This pump supplies fluid at a variable volume and can control the pressure. The cylinder and the drive-shaft are coaxial and rotate taking the pistons which can move up and down in the cylinder. The pistons are a connected to shoes to the non-rotating yoke or swash plate. The angle of the swash-plate and thus the piston stroke is varied by the position of the control piston. This piston is controlled by the outlet pressure on one side of it and a spring on the other. If the pump is stationary there will be no hydraulic pressure and so the spring will push the control piston to the right and the swash-plate angle will be maximum. As the pump begins to rotate the pistons will start moving up and down because of the angle of the swash-plate. If the required operating pressure is reached, the control piston will be pushed back to the left causing the swash-plate to be almost vertical and therefore the pistons’ stroke will be minimal. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. Larger aircraft with multiple main gear wheels often mount the main landing gear on bogie beams, which are excellent for absorbing direct impacts during landing, but can suffer from very high sideways loads during tight turns whilst taxiing. These sideways loads also put a lot of sideways stress on the tyres, which can only rotate forwards and backwards, of course, so will get unnecessarily "scrubbed" during tight turns. This effect can be reduced somewhat by giving the main gear bogie beams a small amount of available steering angle, which is only used in slow speed tight turns, turning the opposite direction of the nose wheel to turn sideways forces into longitudinal forces on the main gear assemblies, thereby reducing stress on the torsional links and reducing tyre abrasion. Let's go through the options: "Insert the ground lock pins." Correct. content.question: How does the emergency landing gear extension usually occur in a modern jet transport aircraft?

options.A: Gravity extension with doors closed by a separate hydraulic actuator.
options.B: Gravity extension with doors closed by a separate electrical actuation.
options.C: Emergency electronic method of lowering the gear with the doors remaining open.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to just drop naturally under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversible operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. The weight of the gear will also push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical downlocks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. There are other systems available for emergency gear extension, such as electrical or pneumatic, but gravity free-fall is so much more common due to its simplicity and lack of potential failure points. It is often aided by pneumatic pressure or a similar system to release the uplocks though.

key_points: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached

An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe

The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice
learning.explanation: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached. An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe. The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice. When the aircraft is stationary on the ground, its weight is supported by the compressed gas in the cylinder. During landing, or when the aircraft taxis over bumps, the piston slides up and down. This movement compresses the gas, which acts as a spring, and forces oil through the orifice, which acts as a damper. A tapered rod is used on some designs to change the size of the orifice as the piston moves, providing greater resistance as compression of the strut increases. Additionally, a check valve is sometimes used to uncover additional orifices so that damping during compression is less than during rebound. Oleo struts absorb and dissipate forces by converting and emitting a portion of the accumulated kinetic energy into thermal energy.

Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second)
This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc
learning.explanation: The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

content.question: How do aircraft parking brakes work?

options.A: They trap hydraulic fluid using a shut-off valve to continuously apply the wheel brakes whilst set.
options.B: They reduce the hydraulic pressure applied to the brakes to that required for parking, which is much less than during landing.
options.C: They operate without hydraulic pressure by mechanically locking the brake pads to the brake disks, therefore providing plenty of braking action whilst the aircraft is parked and hydraulic power is not available.
options.D: They are independent wheel-braking systems which provides hydraulic power for braking action when the aircraft is shut down and parked.

key_points: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics

On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel
The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate
learning.explanation: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics. On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel. The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate. This is a manual braking system. In light aircraft, the same system is present, but in large aircraft, many thousands of times more braking force is needed, requiring large multi-disk brakes on many more wheels, and your feet are just not able to provide enough force to apply these brakes, no matter how much you go to the gym. This means that the brakes run off the normal hydraulic system, and your feet (or the autobrake - if fitted) are now simply moving a valve to provide more or less hydraulic pressure to the brake actuators. This means that, given large aircraft hydraulic systems can run from 3000 to 5000 psi, these can provide much more braking force, and the power comes from hydraulic pumps, not your feet. PARKING BRAKES Parking brakes operate the same in almost all aircraft, no matter whether you are using manual brakes or a hydraulically assisted system. They use a simple shut-off valve upstream of the brake actuators, and whilst the brakes are being applied, with the pads pushed into the disks, the valve is closed to trap that hydraulic pressure inside the braking system and keep those wheels stopped. The only difference is how much pressure is trapped within the brakes when you set it on. In a light aircraft, you need to push the brakes hard enough when setting the parking brake, or they might not be fully set on. Most large aircraft will not let you make this mistake. If you do leave parking brakes set on for a long time, small leaks within the system may slowly allow the pressure to drop and the brakes might slowly release, or the brakes could go the other way and seize in place, so aircraft should not have them set for too long, and instead chocks and tie-downs should be used to secure aircraft for long periods.

key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane

learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again A hand crank system is often found on aeroplanes with electric gear systems. The crank is employed to turn the gears that operate the actuators manually instead of through the electric motor. If you fly an aeroplane with a hydraulic system, you might use a hydraulic hand pump system to extend the gear when the primary pump fails. You do so by supplying the necessary hydraulic fluid pressure to the actuator cylinders by pumping a hand pump. A freefall system is another method of gear extension used on aeroplanes that have hydraulic gear systems. A control lever is used to open a valve that releases the system pressure. Hydraulic pressure equalizes on both sides of the gear actuators and allow the landing gear to fall into position through the force of gravity and aerodynamic loads. In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the nitrogen is not directly used to actuate the landing gear actuators or brake units but, instead, it applies the pressurized nitrogen to move hydraulic fluid to the actuator.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.06: Describe the various protection devices to avoid inadvertent gear retraction on the ground and explain the implications of taking off with one or more protection devices in place: ground lock (pins); protection devices in the gear retraction mechanism. The landing gear anti-retract pin is a safety device used in aircraft. This pin is inserted into the landing gear mechanism during ground operations, typically as part of the aircraft's parking procedures, maintenance, or pre-flight checks. The primary function of the landing gear anti-retract pin is to prevent the landing gear from retracting while the aircraft is on the ground. If the pin is left in place, it will continue to perform this function after takeoff, preventing the landing gear from retracting. ” INCORRECT

Therefore, it does not provide a predetermined fixed braking force. “Manual braking is always the best stopping technique for a rejected take-off.” INCORRECT. content.question: To enhance brake life in relation to brake wear, it is recommended…

options.B: for carbon brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
options.C: for steel brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
options.D: for both carbon and steel brakes to use differential braking to reduce brake temperatures.

key_points: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life
Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes
Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications
learning.explanation: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life. Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes. Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications. High airplane gross weights and high brake application speeds tend to reduce steel brake life because they require the brakes to absorb a large amount of kinetic energy. Carbon brake wear is primarily dependent on the total number of brake applications — one firm brake application causes less wear than several light applications. Maximum carbon brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a small number of long, moderately firm brake applications instead of numerous light brake applications. This can be achieved by allowing taxi speed to increase from below target speed to above target speed, then using a single firm brake application to reduce speed below the target and repeating if required, rather than maintaining a constant taxi speed using numerous brake applications. Carbon brake wear is much less sensitive to airplane weight and speed than steel brake wear.

content.question:
Which of the following are features of the anti-skid system?
1. Prevents brake application on touchdown
2. Steadily increases brake pressure as the aircraft slows
3. Release brake pressure as the brakes approach maximum temperature
4. Release brake pressure on some wheels on a bogie to allow continued breaking on other wheels
5. Reduces the runway length requirement for take-off

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance. In addition to the main optimised braking function, anti-skid systems offer other functions including: The ASU prevents brake application before touchdown on landing. It will prevent any brake pressure even if brake pedals are pressed before touchdown to allow the stationary wheels to spin-up to speed on contact. Only after spin-up does the ASU allow brake preassure application. The ASU protects against the locking of any wheel during the braking process by avoiding excessive wheel-slip values. The ASU protects against the effects of hydroplanning.

content.question: Consider an aircraft with hydraulically operated brakes and a pneumatically operated emergency braking system, which uses the normal hydraulic brake lines. The aircraft also has an anti-skid system to avoid loss of control and locked wheels during braking. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The anti-skid system will allow for a lower brake temperature when braking hard.
options.B: After using the emergency braking system, the brake pedals will feel softer underfoot.
options.C: Normal braking is available after using the emergency braking system, provided it is operational.
options.D: The emergency braking system will be able to stop in a shorter distance, compared to normal braking.

key_points: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action
This is, of course, a hydraulic system
Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft
learning.explanation: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action. This is, of course, a hydraulic system. Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft. The main benefit of hydraulics is that the fluid is not compressible, so the force from the brake pedal piston is immediately (and completely) transferred onto the brake pads. This applies to an aircraft as well, as the only difference is that large aircraft brakes use multiple brake pads (stators) and brake disks (rotors), and the braking systems are usually supplemented by the high pressure hydraulic systems that run the rest of the aircraft's systems to gain higher forces than just the pilot's feet can produce. The emergency braking system that is mentioned in this question is to be used in the case of a loss of hydraulic pressure, and extra pressure can be gained by firing a single burst of high pressure gas into the brake lines, which then allow the brakes to be used (not nicely, but better than nothing). Because of the gas (most likely Nitrogen to reduce fire risk) now inside the hydraulic brake lines, the force applied to the pedals is not going to be completely applied to the brakes, as some of the pressure is absorbed by the compression of the gas in the lines. This makes the brakes feel "soft" or "spongy" underfoot, and not nearly as reactive or sensitive. After this is used, the brake lines will have to be bled again to remove the remaining air in the system, and replace it completely with hydraulic fluid. The gas canister will be replaced for emergency brake system use in the future. Mention of the anti-skid system is there to throw you off. Anti-skid improves braking by stopping the wheels from locking up, so actually increases brake temperature (or does not affect it, depending on the conditions).

Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.08: Describe the sequence for emergency gear extension: unlocking; operating; down-locking. All aircraft are different in their emergency gear extension, but on the whole, the concept is the same. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. Many system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. We are assuming that "activating the uplocks" in this sense refers to the mechanical unlocking process of the gear uplocks. This is usually a cable that is pulled from the flight deck by some means, which overcomes the spring tension on the uplock, releasing the gear (and/or gear doors) to extend by gravity. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. content.question: After landing, with the autobrake system set to a constant deceleration rate, the use of thrust reversers will...

options.A: decrease the brake pressure.
options.B: change the configuration of the ground spoilers.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately
The correct answer is the same

learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately. The correct answer is the same. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall.
