The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means, these down-locks work automatically and mechanically once the gear reaches the down position. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure. In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case it is hydraulic pressure that powers it. The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively. So now for the second part of the question. The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps. These pumps are driven by the auxiliary gearbox connected to one of the engine shafts. Electric hydraulic pumps are also present, and provide the same amount of pressure, but have a much lower displacement as they are much smaller, weaker pumps. While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. Although the autobrake system is designed to facilitate a smooth landing rollout and keep the aircraft on the runway, pilots must always conduct calculations to ensure that the aircraft does not exceed the available landing distance.

content.question: On landing gear, most stress is carried by a torsion link...

options.A: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.B: on the outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.C: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a large radius turn.
options.D: between the inner and outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.

key_points: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load
Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around
With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction
learning.explanation: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load. Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around. With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction. The torsion link provides that mechanical connection between the inner and the outer cylinder (the wheel and the aircraft) in only one direction, preventing sideways movement, whilst still allowing shock absorption by the oleo in the up and down direction, as it moves in and out due to its "scissor link" design. The torsion link does carry lots of stress, therefore, when the aircraft wants to turn and the wheel does not. For example, a main wheel (without steering capability) going round a tight corner where the aircraft wants to twist sideways but the wheel does not. Even more than this, a bogie beam with multiple attached landing gear going round a similarly small corner, would have huge amounts of stress through the torsion link.

content.question:
The following conditions would result in tyres needing to be replaced before the next flight:
1. Uneven tread wear
2. Small cuts in the tread surface
3. Detachment of tread, exposing the tyre carcass
4. A bulge in the sidewall
5. Oil contamination on the tyre surface

options.A: 1 and 5.

key_points: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation
Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc
Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe
learning.explanation: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation. Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc. Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Note: If you find cuts in the tire, it’s important to make sure that they haven’t cut into the ply of the tire. Any deep cuts extending more than half the width of a rib and deeper than 50 percent of the remaining tread depth are indications for tire replacement. In this case, we believe the examiner is referring to superficial cuts which would make the tyre still airworthy. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. "5. Oil contamination on the tyre surface" Correct. Oil contamination (i.e. brake oil, fuel, tar oil, solvents, chemicals) can degrade the rubber of the tire. Typically, the standard approach involves cleaning the tire with Isopropyl Alcohol. However, if the tire becomes sticky, it becomes necessary to replace the wheel. Hydrocarbons have a detrimental effect on rubber, causing it to lose its essential properties, thereby reducing tire performance.

content.question: Which of these statements about an auto-brake system is correct?

options.A: When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
options.B: On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance
options.C: The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same
options.D: When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm

key_points: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
” INCORRECT

It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers
learning.explanation: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm” INCORRECT. During taxi we only ever use manual braking, therefore, the reference to the use of autobrake during taxi does not make sense. “On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance” INCORRECT. Only a few aircraft do that, I believe the A350 and A380 – where you can actually go into the computer and say “this is the runway we are landing on, and I actually want to vacate at this specific exit” because it has the runway in the database and all the different taxiways off the runway and, therefore, you can use the autobrake and select to vacate at a certain exit and it will make sure you have the right speed to vacate => but that is not the majority of the aeroplanes. Ultimately, it is not very practical because there are a lot of different factors. On most aircrafts, it just provides a fixed deceleration rate but not a fixed landing distance (seen it is subjected to wind as well). You can never say it will precisely take this xxx amount of distance. Hopefully, this makes sense. “The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same” CORRECT. So if you press on the pedals as hard as you possibly can, it’s going to give you a maximum deceleration rate and it will also ensure that the wheels don’t lock up – which is exactly the same as autobrake max/RTO. If you look at the pushbutton, it says MAX - maximum amount of braking so it is the same as if you push on the pedals as hard as you can. (Don’t forget that you’ve got antiskid which works in conjunction with autobrake as well) => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. But the thing with the autobrake is that, as soon as the pilot decides to reject the take off and closes the thrust levers, then the maximum braking pressure gets applied immediately. Whereas, if you were to take off without autobrake, and then decided to abort the take-off, you’d first think about “right, I have got to close the thrust levers” and then you’ve got to think to press on the brake pedals => so, there’s obviously an element of delay in that. And that is why the stopping distance in the event of a manual rejected take off would be greater, even though the brake pressure on the brakes, would be exactly the same under both circumstances. content.question: What happens if the grooves or tread of an aircraft tyre are worn?

options.A: The tyre can be used on the nose wheel only.
options.B: The tyre can never be repaired or retreaded.
options.C: The tyre can be retreaded several times.
options.D: The tyre can be retreaded once.

key_points: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread)
This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away
All the tire needs is a new tread
learning.explanation: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread). This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away. All the tire needs is a new tread. Airplane tires can be expensive: there is no logical reason to scrap a tire for an aircraft when it can be safely and economically reconditioned with a new tread. This is why retreading has been standard practice in the aviation industry for decades. The maximum retread level for the part number is set only after extensive testing and analysis. Some airplane tyres can be safely retreaded up to seven or more times, but there is always a limit and the limit is always set with an abundance of caution. The retread process is easy to understand. A worn tyre is removed from an aircraft. It is sent back to a retreading firm, often a manufacturer of airplane tires. When the firm receives a tire for retreading it is carefully inspected to ensure that it is safe and economical to retread. The tyre is scrapped if technicians consider there to be doubt about its airworthiness.

content.question: Which material(s) is/are the brake discs usually made from?

options.A: Steel
options.B: Carbon

key_points: Learning Objectives 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 021.04.03.01.02: State the different materials used in a disc brake (steel, carbon). All modern aircraft now use disc brakes as their means of slowing down or stopping. Steel and carbon emerge as the principal constituents used in the fabrication of these brake components, each offering unique benefits. Conventional brake discs are typically fashioned from steel, boasting durability, cost-efficiency, and consistent braking performance. Carbon is also harnessed in brake assembly due to its superior heat absorption and dissipation characteristics. Carbon brakes exhibit notably lighter weight compared to their steel counterparts. However, their heightened cost and shorter lifespan mean they are primarily installed on aircraft where weight reduction justifies the additional expense, such as long-haul aircraft.

content.question: The backup system of a retractable undercarriage is of the gravity free fall type. Before the gears can free fall under their own weight, what must be first moved, either by mechanic or electronic means?

options.B: Landing gear lever selected down.

key_points: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails
There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft
A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall
learning.explanation: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-revisable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released (unlocked), either either by mechanic or electronic means. This allows the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means.

content.question: When using the pressurized nitrogen bottle system for emergency landing gear extension…

options.B: The emergency system is automatically activated upon failure of the main system and can be used several times.

options.D: The emergency system is activated manually by pulling a handle in the cockpit, allowing the system to be used several times.

key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane
The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems
These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction
learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the emergency gear extension system is activated by pulling the red EMER GEAR CONTROL handle, allowing a one shot extension of the landing gear. Once activated, nitrogen pressure from the emergency air bottle is released through a shuttle valve to the extend side of the landing gear actuators, extending the gear towards the down and locked position. Once the gear has fully extended, the down locks inside the actuators will engage and the down and locked micro switches will be energised causing the three green down and locked lights to illuminate. Once the emergency gear extension procedure has been used, subsequent retraction of the landing gear cannot be achieved. Ground servicing of the system is required prior to normal use of the system.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about an anti-skid system are correct/incorrect?
(1) The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance
(2) If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid

options.A: (1) is incorrect; (2) is incorrect.
options.B: (1) is correct; (2) is incorrect.

key_points: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems
It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies
A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost
learning.explanation: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems. It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies. A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost. One of the important issues to realize is that the anti-skid system greatly increases the effectiveness of braking. In very simplified terms, the anti-skid system provides the greatest possible brake pressure while not allowing the wheels to lock due to an excessive brake pressure being applied. Without the anti-skid system (manual braking) the braking effectiveness is reduced. "The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance." Correct. These systems use a computer that, during ground movement when braking, which constantly compares the measured values of individual wheels (actual rotational speed) with the desired optimum parameters, providing a slip ratio for maximum braking performance. "If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid." Incorrect. A pilot will never reach the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. The anti-skid system senses when a brake starts to skid and will reduce braking pressure to avoid the wheels from skidding, a pilot won’t come close to the same performance.

During taxi we only ever use manual braking, therefore, the reference to the use of autobrake during taxi does not make sense. “On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides a constant deceleration during landing on a dry runway. (ignoring possible transition effects when the system begins to function)” CORRECT. The autobrake system varies the brake pressure to achieve a deceleration rate (about 1.7 m/sec2 on the A320 in low autobrake mode). So, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll out – it varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always. If it is a contaminated runway and it can’t achieve that rate, fundamentally, it will just achieve what it can achieve. “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When the auto-brake system is inoperative, in general take-off is not allowed, because maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in the RTO mode.” INCORRECT. I would say that this is a bit type specific. However, saying that the maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in RTO IS NOT CORRECT. => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. The same amount of pressure is accomplished, the only benefit of autobrake is that the braking happens immediately, you do not have to wait for a pilot to respond to it. And, therefore, the braking distance without an autobrake is longer => because of the reaction time. content.question: Landing gear torsion links are used to…

options.A: control the rate of oleo strut recoil.
options.B: prevent rotation of the landing gear piston in the oleo strut.
options.C: absorb the lateral stresses to which the gear is subjected.
options.D: prevent extension of the oleo strut when the gear is retracted.

key_points: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder
So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link
When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder. So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link. When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft. When the aircraft is turning on the ground and especially turns with a small radius, the wheels will want to move forward whilst the aircraft is turning, this will cause a lot of load on the torsion link.

content.question: The auto-brake system is disarmed during landing...

options.A: below a specific speed.
options.B: after a preset elapsed time.

key_points: Basic auto-brake information below, which states that the auto-brake system is only disarmed by Pilot action
The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO)
There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating
learning.explanation: Basic auto-brake information below, which states that the auto-brake system is only disarmed by Pilot action. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated.

content.question: Light aircraft and helicopters may equipped with a “blowdown” emergency gear extension system for use in case of hydraulic failure. Which gasses are used for this purpose, and how are the gasses sent to the actuators?

options.A: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.
options.B: Helium or nitrogen, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.C: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.D: Helium or carbon dioxide, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main hydraulic system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. This is common for large aircraft as their gear are very heavy. Unfortunately, in light aircraft, the gear components are not as heavy, so can get jammed in place with not very much force. This includes the "blowdown" system using compressed gasses. The action of emergency gear extension is often a one-way movement, and cannot be reversed. In order to activate the system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through one of the following systems. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. Some emergency extension systems (as mentioned above) use bottles of compressed air or compressed nitrogen to extend the gear, thereby overcoming any small jams that would otherwise keep the gear in the up position. Nitrogen is better as it is non-flammable, and air contains oxygen, which will feed a potential fire. Compressed air is easier (and cheaper) to bottle though. The gear will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical down locks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. The shuttle valve mentioned in this question is a way to feed one actuator with two different pressure sources. When one pressure source loses pressure, the piston can slide across from blocking the emergency source to blocking the usual source, allowing out the emergency pressure to feed the actuator. This can be automatic or manually controlled. A diagram of the shuttle valve is shown in the annex above.

learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question: The retraction mechanism of the landing gear is...

options.A: an active system and operated with the engine pump.
options.B: an active system and operated with the pressure pump.
options.C: a passive system and operated with the engine pump.
options.D: a passive system and operated with the pressure pump.

key_points: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it
The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively
The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps
learning.explanation: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it. The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively. The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps. These pumps are driven by the auxiliary gearbox connected to one of the engine shafts. Electric hydraulic pumps are also present, and provide the same amount of pressure, but have a much lower displacement as they are much smaller, weaker pumps. Therefore, when landing gear is raised, the vast majority of the load is placed on the engine driven pumps, and is therefore fed by power from the auxiliary gearbox.

Therefore, on a dry runway, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll, autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always. However, if the runway is contaminated and has slippery spots, brakes might be released in order to prevent skidding. Brake release will consequently reduce deceleration rate. learning.explanation: Undercarriage locks Any retractable undercarriage has to be locked when in the up (retracted) and down (extended) positions. Types of lock Over centre Lock The over-centre lock or "geometric lock" is mainly used as a downlock. It will require a mechanical force to release the lock. The locks can be formed by using the stays bracing struts. They do not require much to lock, so are used also in the case of emergency gear extension, as they will lock as soon as the gear is fully extended. They allow the side- or front-stays to be kept in line using a very small locking force, which means the main stays remain strong Hook Lock The hook lock will lock automatically, without hydraulic pressure, but require hydraulic pressure input to unlock. These type of locks are normally used as uplocks, but they can rarely be used as a downlock.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the autobrake system during landing?

options.B: It is possible to choose a fixed stopping distance.
options.C: It will remain active until the aircraft comes to a stop, unless disconnected by the pilot.
options.D: It is disconnected automatically if thrust reversers are used.

key_points: Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration
There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration
Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work
learning.explanation: Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration. There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration. Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. Autobrakes will be disarmed during use by any of the following conditions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. Otherwise, the autobrake system will continue meeting a selected rate of deceleration until making a complete stop. Whilst one of the other options mentions setting a fixed stopping distance, this is a lot more complex than it sounds, but a system like this has been implemented on newer Airbus A380 and A350 aircraft called BTV (Brake to Vacate). EASA are not yet including this in the learning objectives or questions, so assume it does not exist for the ATPL exams.

The sidewall is the bit on the side of the tyre that connects the tread to the "bead", which is fitted to the wheel rim, it is a very vulnerable section of the tyre, with less protection. Objects embedded in the tyre cause obvious damage to the structural integrity, which could lead to blow outs or slow punctures, both of which are very bad for any ground movements, take off and landing. Note: We are well aware that the pilot should check for both embedded objects and tyre creep when performing their walk around, so would be inclined to appeal this question if it came up in this format. This is correct, when performing a rudder check without disconnecting the nose wheel steering the nose wheel would follow the input on the rudder pedals and would make the aircraft move from left to right while taxiing.

Which of the following is correct about multi-disc steel brakes as opposed to single disc carbon brakes?
1. Multiple small applications is best
2. Small numbers of strong applications is best
3. They operate best at a higher brake temperature
4. They operate best at a lower brake temperature
5. They have higher braking strength
6. They have lower braking strength

options.A: 1, 3 and 4
options.B: 2, 4 and 6

key_points: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received

The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes
Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes
learning.explanation: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received. The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes. Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes. The only difference in answer can occur if they compare multi-disc steel brakes to multi-disc carbon brakes directly, in which case the carbon brakes have higher braking strength usually. Please let us know what was actually on the exam if you do see this, and we can adjust it as necessary, thanks! The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them many times, but softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible, and because their wear is more linked to amount of applications, rather than total heat input. In most transport aircraft, the brakes need to absorb vast amounts of heat during landings, rejected take-offs and taxiing, much more than could be absorbed by a single disk and pair of brake pads. Therefore, their brakes are usually made up of multiple (spinning) brake discs separated by multiple (static) rings of brake pads. These multiple rings of stators and rotors can provide much stronger braking and absorb far more heat than a single disc and pair of pads alone, steel or carbon.

content.question:
Which of the following items are performed as part of the pilot's pre-flight inspection of an aircraft's tyres?
1. An inspection for excessive tyre creep
2. A check of the ply and speed rating of each tyre
3. Measurement of the actual tread depth using a tread-depth gauge
4. Visual tyre inspection for embedded objects
5. Measurement of the tyre pressure using a pressure gauge

options.A: 1 and 4
options.B: 1 and 5

key_points: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation
Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc
Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion
learning.explanation: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation. Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc. Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. A check of the ply/speed rating, tread depth measurement, and tyre pressure measurement is usually the job of an engineer, and is not required before every single flight, however checking tyre creep and embedded objects are quick enough, and important enough tasks to require a check of every tyre before flight.

content.question:
The autobrake system is deactivated:
1) below a preset minimum speed
2) when reverse thrust is activated

options.A: 1) is incorrect, 2) is correct
options.B: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect

key_points: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed
Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed
Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated
learning.explanation: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed. Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed. Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated. Incorrect, the autobrake remains active also when reverse thrust is activated. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated.

content.question: For aircraft equipped with a landing gear anti retract latch, which of these statements is correct?

options.A: This system can be overridden under specified conditions.
options.B: This system may never be overridden since an uncentred nose wheel can damage the wheel well structure.
options.C: This system blocks gear retraction at too low IAS.
options.D: This system blocks gear retraction at too high IAS.

key_points: An anti-retract latch is fitted to prevent inadvertent up selection of the landing gear when on the ground, this anti-retract latch physically prevents the gear selector from being moved
The air/ground logic system will still work as a back-up and will prevent the gear from operating when on the ground
In an emergency the pilot might be able to override an anti-retract latch and retract the gear
learning.explanation: An anti-retract latch is fitted to prevent inadvertent up selection of the landing gear when on the ground, this anti-retract latch physically prevents the gear selector from being moved. The air/ground logic system will still work as a back-up and will prevent the gear from operating when on the ground. In an emergency the pilot might be able to override an anti-retract latch and retract the gear. If the up selection is made on the ground when the aircraft is stationary, the gear warning horn will sound and a red gear unsafe light will illuminate.

content.question: An anti-retract latch blocks the landing gear lever when...

options.B: the IAS is too high for gear retraction.

Usually there is no lower speed limit for gear retraction
The IAS is too high for gear retraction
learning.explanation: An anti-retract latch blocks the landing gear lever when: The IAS is too low for gear retraction. Usually there is no lower speed limit for gear retraction. The IAS is too high for gear retraction. This could make sense, but this is not how the anti-retract latch blocks work. The gear is in an improper configuration for extension. This is a strange answer as the question mentions anti-retract latch block and this answer is related to extension. An aircraft is on the ground. This is correct as retracting the gears on the ground would give major damage to an aircraft and should be avoided.

content.question: What will happen if a dual control input is made on an Airbus type Fly-By-Wire flight control system?

options.A: The last input would take priority over the first.
options.B: The first input would take priority over the last.
options.C: The conflicting inputs would cancel each other out.
options.D: Both inputs would be summed together by the Fly-By-Wire computer.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: You are flying a FBW (Fly-By-Wire) aircraft in a 30-degree angle of bank turn when the bank angle protection system activates due to a failure. What will happen?

options.A: The auto-pilot engages in heading mode
options.B: The aircraft downgrades to direct law
options.C: The aircraft will roll to wings level
options.D: Increased stick force will be required to maintain or increase the bank angle

key_points: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording
The answer is quite similar

Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording. The answer is quite similar. Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, moving the flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which significantly enhances safety. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft can change the effect of control inputs to make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. For instance, in the Airbus A320, above 33°, force is needed to maintain the bank angle. The aircraft will not allow bank angles past 67° in normal law. In this question the bank angle protections have activated improperly at 30° AoB, so more force will be required to maintain or increase the angle of bank.

As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: In a fully manual flight control system, the pilot must exert sufficient force to...

options.A: separate each pilot`s yaw control in the case of a jam.
options.B: overcome the aerodynamic loads felt at the control surface.
options.D: allow pressure to build up in the flight control actuators.

key_points: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls
So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls. So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

3- By pressing the takeover pushbutton
